sp.p: with a sighI would n't stand in her way , Cornelius ; I would n't stand in her way . But wo n't it be a poor thing for an old man like me to have no one to discourse with in the long evenings ? For when I 'm talking with you , Cornelius , I feel like a boy who lends back all the marbles he 's won , and plays again , just for the sake of the game .

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: We were in dread of Ellen going to America at one time , and then she went in for the school . Now Matt Cosgar may keep her from the school . Maybe we wo n't have to go further than this house to see Ellen .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: I 'm hoping it 'll be like that ; but I 'm in dread that Murtagh Cosgar will never agree to it . He 's a hard man to deal with . Still Murtagh and myself will be on the long road to-night , and we might talk of it . I 'm afeard of Ellen going .

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: at the doorIt 's herself that 's coming here , father .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: Maybe she has heard the news and is coming to tell us . Ellen comes in . She has a shawl over her head which she lays aside . She is about twenty-five , slightly built , nervous , emotional .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: Is it only ourselves that 's here ?

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: Only ourselves . Did you get any news to bring you over , Ellen ?

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: No news . It was the shine of the day that brought me out ; and I was thinking , too , of the girls that are going to America in the morning , and that made me restless . Martin and Cornelius look significantly at each other .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: And did you see Matt , Ellen ?

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: He was in the field and I coming up ; but I did not wait for him , as I do n't want people to see us together .RestlesslyI do n't know how I can come into this house , for it 's always like Murtagh Cosgar . There 's nothing of Matt in it at all . If Matt would come away . There are little labourers ’ houses by the side of the road . Many 's the farmer 's son became a labourer for the sake of a woman he cared for !

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: And are you not thinking about the school at all , Ellen ?

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: I 'll hear about it some time , I suppose .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: You 're right to take it that way , Ellen . School does n't mean scholarship now . Many 's the time I 'm telling Cornelius that a man farming the land , with a few books on his shelf and a few books in his head , has more of the scholar 's life about him than the young fellows who do be teaching in schools and teaching in colleges .

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: That 's all very well , father . School and scholarship is n't the one . But think of the word “ Constantinople ! ” I could leave off herding and digging every time I think on that word !

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: Ah , it 's a great word . A word like that would make you think for days . And there are many words like that .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: It 's not so much the long words that we 've to learn and teach now . When will you be home , father ? Will Cornelius be with you ?

lg.l: Ellen , I have news for you . There is a school in
Leitrim that Father Bartley can let you have .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: In Leitrim ! Did you tell Matt about it ?

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: I did not . Sally is heard calling “ Cornelius . ” Cornelius goes to the door .

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: Here 's Matt now . The benefit of the day to you , Matt . He stands aside to let Matt enter . Matt Cosgar is a young peasant of about twenty-eight . He is handsome and well-built . He is dressed in a trousers , shirt , and coat , and has a felt hat on . Cornelius goes out .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: going to EllenYou 're welcome , Ellen . Good morrow , Martin . It 's a great day for the purchase , Martin .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: A great day , indeed , thank God .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Ah , it 's a great thing to feel the ownership of the land , Martin .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: I do n't doubt but it is .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Look at the young apple-trees , Ellen . Walking up this morning , I felt as glad of them as a young man would be glad of the sweetheart he saw coming towards him .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: Ay , there 's great gladness and shine in the day .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: It seems to trouble you .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: It does trouble me .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: Everything seems to be saying , “ There 's something here , there 's something going . ”

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Ay , a day like this often makes you feel that way . It 's a great day for the purchase though . How many years ought we to offer , Ellen ? Martin goes out .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: Twenty years , I suppose — -suddenlyMatt !

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: What is it , Ellen ?

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: I have got an offer of a school in the County Leitrim .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: I wish they 'd wait , Ellen . I wish they 'd wait till I had something to offer you .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: I 'm a long time waiting here , Matt .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Sure we 're both young .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: This is summer now . There will be autumn in a month or two . The year will have gone by without bringing me anything .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: He 'll be letting me have my own way soon , my father will .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: Murtagh Cosgar never let a child of his have their own way .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: When the land 's bought out , he 'll be easier to deal with .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: When he owns the land , he 'll never let a son of his marry a girl without land or fortune .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Ellen , Ellen , I 'd lose house and land for you . Sure you know that , Ellen . My brothers and sisters took their freedom . They went from this house and away to the ends of the world . Maybe I do n't differ from them so much . But I 've put my work into the land , and I 'm beginning to know the land . I wo n't lose it , Ellen . Neither will I lose you .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: O Matt , what 's the land after all ? Do you ever think of America ? The streets , the shops , the throngs ?

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: The land is better than that when you come to know it , Ellen .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: May be it is .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: I 've set my heart on a new house . Ay and he 'll build one for us when he knows my mind .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: Do you think he 'd build a new house for us , Matt ? I could settle down if we were by ourselves . Maybe it 's true that there are things stirring and we could begin a new life , even here .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: We can , Ellen , we can . Hush ! father 's without . Martin Douras and Murtagh Cosgar are heard exchanging greetings . Then Murtagh comes in , Martin behind him . Murtagh Cosgar is about sixty . He is a hard , strong man , seldom-spoken , but with a flow of words and some satirical power . He is still powerful , mentally and physically . He is clean shaven , and wears a sleeved waistcoat , heavy boots , fell hat . He goes towards Ellen .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH
sp.p: Good morrow to you .Turning to MattWhen I get speaking to that Sally again , she 'll remember what I say . Giving cabbage to the pigs , and all the bad potatoes in the house . And I had to get up in the clouds of the night to turn the cows out of the young meadow . No thought , no care about me . Let you take the harness outside and put a thong where there 's a strain in it . Murtagh goes to the fire . Matt goes to the harness-rack . Martin Douras and Ellen are at the door .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: Ellen , I 'll have news for you when I see you again . I 've made up my mind to that .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: Are you going to the fair , father ?

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: Ay , with Murtagh .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: God be with you , father .She goes out

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: What purchase are you thinking of offering , Murtagh ?

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Twenty years .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: It 's fair enough . Oh , it 's a great day for the country , no matter what our own troubles may be . Matt has taken down the harness . He takes some of it up and goes out to yard .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: with some contemptIt 's a pity you have n't a share in the day after all .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: Ay , it 's a pity indeed . Murtagh goes to the door .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: with suppressed enthusiasmFrom this day out we 're planted in the soil .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: Ay , we 're planted in the soil .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: God , it 's a great day . Cornelius comes back .

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: This is a memorial occasion , Murtagh Cosgar , and I wish you the felicitations of it . I met the delegates and I coming in , and I put myself at the head of them . It 's the day of the redemption , Murtagh Cosgar . Murtagh , without speaking , goes up to the room .

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: He 's gone up to get the papers . Father , we must give the men understanding for this business . They must demand the mineral rights . Here they are . Men of Ballykillduff , I greet your entrance . Six men enter discussing .

sp.speaker: FIRST
sp.p: MAN We 'll leave it to Murtagh Cosgar . Murtagh Cosgar is n't a grazier or a shopkeeper .

sp.speaker: SECOND MAN
sp.p: It 's the graziers and shopkeepers that are putting a business head on this .

sp.speaker: THIRD MAN
sp.p: If we 're all on the one offer , we can settle it at the lawyer 's .

sp.speaker: FOURTH MAN
sp.p: Sure it 's settled for twenty years on the first-term rents .

sp.speaker: FIFTH MAN
sp.p: There are some here that would let it go as high as twenty-three .

sp.speaker: SIXTH MAN
sp.p: What does Murtagh Cosgar say ?

sp.speaker: SOME OF THE MEN
sp.p: Well take the word from him .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: He mentioned twenty years .

sp.speaker: SECOND MAN
sp.p: Not as a limit , surely ?

sp.speaker: OTHER MEN
sp.p: We 're not for any higher offer .

sp.speaker: SECOND MAN
sp.p: Well , men , this is all I have to say . If you can get it for twenty , take it , and my blessing with it . But I want to be dealing with the Government , and not with landlords and agents . To have a straight bargain between myself and the Government , I 'd put it up to twenty-three , ay , up to twenty-five years ’ purchase .

sp.speaker: THIRD MAN
sp.p: More power to you , Councillor . There 's some sense in that .

sp.speaker: SIXTH MAN
sp.p: I 'm with the Councillor .

sp.speaker: FIRST MAN
sp.p: It 's all very well for graziers and shopkeepers to talk , but what about the small farmer ?

sp.speaker: FOURTH MAN
sp.p: The small farmer . That 's the man that goes under .

sp.speaker: FIFTH MAN
sp.p: knocking at the tableMurtagh Cosgar ! Murtagh Cosgar !

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: I tell you , men , that Murtagh Cosgar is in agreement with myself . Twenty years , I say , first term , no more . Let my father speak .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: There 's a great deal to be said on both sides , men .

sp.speaker: FIRST MAN
sp.p: Here 's Murtagh now .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Twenty years first term , that 's what I agreed to .

sp.speaker: SECOND MAN
sp.p: And if they do n't rise to that , Murtagh ?

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Let them wait . We can wait . I wo n't be going with you , men . I had a few words with the agent about the turbary this morning , and maybe you 're better without me .

sp.speaker: FIRST MAN
sp.p: All right , Murtagh . We can wait .

sp.speaker: FOURTH MAN
sp.p: We know our own power now .

sp.speaker: FIFTH MAN
sp.p: Come on , men .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: If they do n't rise to it , bide a while . We can make a new offer .

sp.speaker: SECOND MAN
sp.p: We want to be settled by the Fall .

sp.speaker: THIRD MAN
sp.p: The Councillor is right . We must be settled by the Fall .

sp.speaker: SIXTH MAN
sp.p: A man who 's a farmer only has little sense for a business like this .

sp.speaker: SECOND MAN
sp.p: We 'll make the offer , Murtagh Cosgar , and bide a while . But we must be settled this side of the Fall . We 'll offer twenty years first term .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Do , and God speed you .

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: to the men going outI told you Murtagh Cosgar and myself are on the one offer . And Murtagh is right again when he says that you can bide your time . But make sure of the mineral rights , men ; make sure of the mineral rights . The men go out ; Cornelius follows them .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: with ironyMusha , but that 's a well-discoursed lad . It must be great to hear the two of you at it .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: God be good to Cornelius . There 's little of the world 's harm in the boy .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: He and my Sally would make a great match of it . She 's a bright one , too .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: Murtagh Cosgar , have you no feeling for your own flesh and blood ?

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Too much feeling , maybe .He stands at the door in silence . With sudden enthusiasmAh , but that 's the sight to fill one 's heart . Lands ploughed and spread . And all our own ; all our own .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: All our own , ay . But we made a hard fight for them .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Ay .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: Them that come after us will never see them as we 're seeing them now .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: turning roundThem that come after us . Is n't that a great thought , Martin Douras ? and is n't it a great thing that we 're able to pass this land on to them , and it redeemed for ever ? Ay , and their manhood spared the shame that our manhood knew . Standing in the rain with our hats off to let a landlord — ay , or a landlord 's dog-boy — pass the way !

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: mournfullyMay it be our own generation that will be in it . Ay , but the young are going fast ; the young are going fast .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: sternlySome of them are no loss .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: Ten of your own children went , Murtagh Cosgar .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: I never think of them . When they went from my control , they went from me altogether . There 's the more for Matt .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: moistening his mouth , and beginning very nervouslyAy , Matt . Matt 's a good lad .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: There 's little fear of him leaving now .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: nervouslyMaybe , maybe . But , mind you , Murtagh Cosgar , there are things — little things , mind you . Least , ways , what we call little things . And , after all , who are we to judge whether a thing —

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Is there anything on your mind , Martin Douras ?

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: hurriedlyNo ; oh , no . I was thinking — I was thinking , maybe you 'd give me a lift towards Arvach , if you 'd be going that way this night .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Ay , why not ?

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: And we could talk about the land , and about Matt , too . Would n't it be a heart-break if any of our children went — because of a thing we might —

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: fiercelyWhat have you to say about Matt ?

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: stammeringNothing except in a — in what you might call a general way . There 's many a young man left house and land for the sake of some woman , Murtagh Cosgar .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: There 's many a fool did it .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: going to doorAy , maybe ; maybe . I 'll be going now , Murtagh .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Stop !clutching himYou know about Matt . What woman is he thinking of ?

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: frightenedWe 'll talk about it again , Murtagh . I said I 'd be back .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: We 'll talk about it now . Who is she ? What name has she ?

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: breaking from him and speaking with sudden dignityIt 's a good name , Murtagh Cosgar ; it 's my own name .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Your daughter ! Ellen ! You 're —

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: Ay , a good name , and a good girl .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: And do you think a son of mine would marry a daughter of yours ?

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: What great difference is between us , after all ?

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: fiercelyThe daughter of a man who 'd be sitting over his fire reading his paper , and the clouds above his potatoes , and the cows trampling his oats .Martin is beaten downDo you know me at all , Martin Douras ? I came out of a little house by the roadway and built my house on a hill . I had many children . Coming home in the long evenings , or kneeling still when the prayers would be over , I 'd have my dreams . A son in Aughnalee , a son in Ballybrian , a son in Dunmore , a son of mine with a shop , a son of mine saying Mass in Killnalee . And I have a living name — a name in flesh and blood .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: God help you , Murtagh Cosgar .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: But I 've a son still . It 's not your daughter he 'll be marrying .He strides to the door and calls Matt

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: going to himMurtagh Cosgar — for God 's sake — we 're both old men , Murtagh Cosgar .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: You 've read many stories , Martin Douras , and you know many endings . You 'll see an ending now , and it will be a strong ending , and a sudden ending .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: I heard you call .He sits on tableSo they 're sticking to the twenty years .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: eagerlyTwenty years , Matt , and they 'll get it for twenty . O , it 's a great day for you both ! Father and son , you come into a single inheritance . What the father wins the son wields .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: What the father wins , the son wastes .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: What 's the talk of father and son ?

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: They 're the one flesh and blood . There 's no more strife between them than between the right hand and the left hand .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: to MattWe were talking about you . We were fixing a match for you .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: startled , looking at Martin DourasFixing a match for me ?He rises

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Ay , Matt . Do n't you think it 's time to be making a match for you ?

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: sullenly , going to the doorMaybe it is . When you have chosen the woman , call . I 'll be without .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: going to himWe have n't chosen yet . But it wo n't be Martin Douras ’ daughter , anyhow .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Stop . You drove all your living children away , except Sally and myself . You think Sally and myself are the one sort .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: tauntinglyMartin 's daughter , Corney 's sister . That 's the girl for you !

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: We 're not the one sort , I tell you . Martin Douras , is n't he a foolish old man that would drive all his children from him ? What would his twenty years ’ purchase be to him then ?

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: It was n't for my children I worked . No , no ; thank God ; it was n't for my children I worked . Go , if you will . I can be alone .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: O Murtagh , Murtagh , sure you know you can n't be alone . We 're two old men , Murtagh .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: He dare n't go .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Because I 'm the last of them he thinks he can dare me like that .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: There was more of my blood in the others .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Do you say that ?

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: Do n't say it again . For God 's sake , do n't say it again , Murtagh .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: I do say it again . Them who dared to go had more of my blood in them !

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Ah , you have put me to it now , and I 'm glad , glad . A little house , a bit of land . Do you think they could keep me here ?

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: to Martin DourasIt 's his own way he wants . I never had my own way .To MattYou 're my last son . You 're too young to know the hardship there was in rearing you .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: exultantlyYour last son ; that wo n't keep me here . I 'm the last of my name , but that wo n't keep me here . I leave you your lands , your twenty years ’ purchase . Murtagh Cosgar , Murtagh Cosgar ! is n't that a great name , Martin Douras — a name that 's well planted , a name for generations ? Is n't he a lucky man that has a name for generations ?He goes out

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: He can n't go . How could he go and he the last of the name . Close the door , I say .

lg.l: He 'll go to Ellen , surely . We 'll lose both of them . Murtagh Cosgar ,

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Ellen ; who 's Ellen ? Ay , that daughter of yours . Close the door , I say . He sits down at fireplace . Martin Douras closes door and goes to him .

div.head: ACT II

stage.stage: Interior of Martin Douras ’ . The entrance is at back left . There is a dresser against wall back ; a table down from dresser ; room doors right and left . The fireplace is below the room door right ; there are stools and chairs about it . There is a little bookcase left of the dresser , and a mirror beside it . There are patriotic and religious pictures on the wall . There are cups and saucers on table , and a teapot beside fire . It is afternoon still . Ellen Douras is near the fire reading . Cornelius comes in slowly .

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: I left the men down the road a bit . We ought to take great pride out of this day , Ellen . Father did more than any of them to bring it about .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: He suffered more than any of them . And it 's little we 'll get out of the day .

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: It 's a great thing to have prophesied it , even . We 'll be here to see a great change .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: There will be no change to make things better !

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: Will you be taking that school , Ellen ?

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: I 'll wait a while . Sally coming in ; she is hurried .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: breathlesslyOh , God save you , Cornelius . Tell me , is my father gone ? I dread going back and he there ! It was all over that baste of a sow that has kept me slaving all through the spring till I do n't know whether greens or potatoes is the fittest for her !

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: He did n't go , Sally . I went down a bit of the road myself with the men .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Oh , God help me ! And I 'll have to be going back to boil meal for her now . How are you , Ellen .She goes to Ellen

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: Sit down for a while , Sally ; it 's a long time since I was speaking to you . Sally sits down beside Ellen .

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: I 'll leave this paper where they wo n't be looking for pipe-lights . There are things in that paper I 'd like to be saying .He takes a newspaper out of his pocket and goes to room right

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: to Sally , who has been watching CorneliusTell me , Sally , are they always that busy in your house ? Is your father as harsh as they say ?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Father ‘ ud keep us all working . He 's a powerful great man .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: Matt will be bringing a wife into the house soon from all I hear . How would your father treat her ?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Oh , he 'd have his way , and she 'd have her way , I suppose .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: And do you think your father will let him marry ?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Sure he must if the boy likes .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: What would he say if Matt married a girl without a fortune ?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: In my mother 's country there are lots of girls with fortunes that Matt could have .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: Supposing he wanted a girl that had no fortune ?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Oh , I suppose father would give in in the end . It would n't be clay against flint when Matt and father would be to it .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: You 're a good girl , Sally . If I was Matt 's wife , do you think you 'd be fond of me ?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: I 'd like you as well as another , Ellen . Cornelius comes down from room .

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: I suppose they 'll be here soon .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: I have tea ready for them .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Who 's coming at all ?

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: Some of the boys and girls that are for America . They are going to Gilroy 's to-night , and are leaving from that in the morning . They are coming in to see Ellen on their way down .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: There are a good many going this flight . The land never troubles them in America , and they can wear fine clothes , and be as free as the larks over the bogs . It 's a wonder you never thought of going , Ellen .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: Father would n't like me to be far from him , and so I went in for the school instead .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: And now you 've got a fine boy like Matt . It was lucky for you to be staying here .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: Hush , Sally .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Oh , I knew all about it before you talked to me at all . Matt always goes to the place where he thinks you 'd be .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: risingI 'll be in the room when the girls come , Cornelius . She goes into room left .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: going to CorneliusGod help us , but she 's the silent creature . Is n't it a wonder she 's not filled with talk of him after seeing him to-day ? But Ellen 's right . We should n't be talking about men , nor thinking about them either ; and that 's the way to keep them on our hands on the long run . I 'll be going myself . She goes towards door .

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: going to herDo n't be minding Ellen at all , Sally .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Well , as high as she is , and as mighty as she is , she came into his own house to see Matt . God between us and harm , Cornelius , maybe they 'll be saying I came into your house to see you .

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: Who 'll know you came at all ? And what is n't seen wo n't be spoken of .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Would you like me to stay , Cornelius ?

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: Ay , I would .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: after a pauseWould you like me to knit you a pair of socks , Cornelius ?

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: Oh , I would , Sally ; I 'd love to wear them .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: I 'll knit them . We 'll be getting rid of the sow tonight , maybe , and I 'll have time after that .

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: And you come along the road when I 'm herding . I do n't want to be going near your father 's house .

lg.l: O Cornelius , it wo n't be lucky for us when father hears about

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: That 's true . No man sees his house afire but looks to his rick .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Come down a bit of the road with me , Cornelius . The sow will be grunting and grunting , reminding father that I 'm away . Och , a minute ago I was as contented as if there was no land or pigs , or harsh words to trouble one .She goes to the doorThe boys and girls for America are coming here .

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: Give me your hands to hold , Sally .She gives him her handsWe are as young as any of them after all . They hold each other 's hands , then stand apart .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: It 's a fine time for them to be going when the leaves are opening on the trees . Three boys and three girls enter . They are dressed for going away .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: God save you , girls . Good-bye , Cornelius . I 'll have to run like a redshank .

sp.speaker: Sally goes out
sp.p: CORNELIUS I 'll call Ellen down to you .He goes to the room door and callsI 'm going herding myself . Herding is pleasant when you have thoughts with you . He takes up the rod and goes out . The girls begin whispering , then chattering .

sp.speaker: FIRST GIRL
sp.p: Sure I know . Every night I 'm dreaming of the sea and the great towns . Streets and streets of houses and every street as crowded as the road outside the chapel when the people do be coming from Mass . I could watch the crowd in the street ; I would think it better than any sight I ever knew .

sp.speaker: SECOND GIRL
sp.p: And the shops and the great houses .

sp.speaker: SECOND BOY
sp.p: There 's no stir here . There 's no fine clothes , nor fine manners , nor fine things to be seen .

sp.speaker: THIRD BOY
sp.p: There 's no money . One could never get a shilling together here . In America there 's money to have and to spend and to send home .

sp.speaker: THIRD GIRL
sp.p: Every girl gets married in America . Ellen comes down .

lg.l: I 'm glad you came . I have tea ready for you . I can n't go to
Some come to the table and some remain near the door .

sp.speaker: A GIRL
sp.p: at table , to EllenThey say that a peat fire like that will seem very strange to us after America . Bridget wondered at it when she came back . “ Do civilized people really cook at the like of them ? ” said she .

sp.speaker: A BOY
sp.p: It 's the little houses with only three rooms in them that will seem strange . I 'm beginning to wonder myself at their thatch and their mud walls .

sp.speaker: ANOTHER GIRL
sp.p: Houses in bogs and fields . It was a heart-break trying to keep them as we 'd like to keep them . A GIRLat doorAh , but I 'll never forget Gortan and the little road to Aughnalee .

sp.speaker: ANOTHER GIRL
sp.p: I think I 'll be lonesome for a long time . I 'll be thinking on my brothers and sisters . I nursed and minded all the little ones .

sp.speaker: FIRST BOY
sp.p: A girl like you , Ellen , is foolish to be staying here .

lg.l: She 'll be coming in the fall . We 'll be glad to see you ,

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: I have no friends in America .

sp.speaker: FIRST GIRL
sp.p: I have no friends there , either . But I 'll get on . You could get on better than any of us , Ellen .

sp.speaker: SECOND GIRL
sp.p: She 's waiting for her school . It will be a little place by the side of a bog .

sp.speaker: THIRD GIRL
sp.p: going to EllenThere would be little change in that . And is n't it a life altogether different from this life that we have been longing for ? To be doing other work , and to be meeting strange people . And instead of bare roads and market-towns , to be seeing streets , and crowds , and theaters .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: passionatelyO what do you know about streets and theaters ? You have only heard of them . They are finer than anything you could say . They are finer than anything you could think of , after a story , when you 'd be A GIRL You 'll be going after all , Ellen .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: I wo n't be going .

sp.speaker: FIRST GIRL
sp.p: Well , maybe you 'll be down at Gilroy 's . We must go now . The girls go to the door . Ellen goes with them .

sp.speaker: ONE OF THE BOYS
sp.p: Phil said that an egg was all he could touch while he was on the sea .

sp.speaker: SECOND BOY
sp.p: God help us , if that was all Phil could take .

sp.speaker: THIRD BOY
sp.p: Light your pipes now , and we 'll go . Ellen has parted with the girls . The boys light their pipes at fire . They go to door , and shake hands with Ellen . The boys go out .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: Theaters ! What do they know of theaters ? And it 's their like will be enjoying them . Sally comes back . She is more hurried than before .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Ellen ! Ellen ! I have wonders to tell . Where is Cornelius , at all ? He 's never here when you have wonders to tell .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: What have you to tell ?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Oh , I do n't know how I 'll get it all out ! Matt and father had an odious falling out , and it was about you . And Matt 's going to America ; and he 's to bring you with him . And Cornelius was saying that if father found out about yourself and Matt —

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: Sally , Sally , take breath and tell it .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Matt is going to America , like the others , and he 's taking you with him .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: Sally , Sally , is it the truth you 're telling ?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: It is the truth . Honest as day , it is the truth .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: And I thought I 'd be content with a new house . Now we can go away together . I can see what I longed to see . I have a chance of knowing what is in me .She takes Sally 's handsIt 's great news you 've brought me . No one ever brought me such news before . Take this little cross . You wo n't have a chance of getting fond of me after all .She wears a cross at her throat ; she breaks the string , and gives it to Sally

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: I do n't know why I was so fervent to tell you . There 's the stool before me that myself and Cornelius were sitting on , and he saying —She goes to the doorHere 's Matt ! Now we 'll hear all about it .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: So soon ; so soon .She goes to the mirror . After a pause , turning to SallyGo down the road a bit , when he comes in . Sally , you have a simple mind ; you might be saying a prayer that it will be for the best .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: going to the door mutteringGo down the road a bit ! ‘ Deed and I will not till I know the whole ins and outs of it . Sure I 'm as much concerned in it as herself ! “ No man sees his house afire but watches his rick , ” he was saying . Ah , there 's few of them could think of as fine a thing as that .

lg.l: Well , Sally , were you home lately ?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: I was — leastways as far as the door . Father and oul ’ Martin were discoursing .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: I 've given them something to discourse about . Maybe you 'll be treated better from this day . Sally .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: O Matt , I 'm sorry .

sp.speaker: She goes out
sp.p: MATTgoing to EllenIt happened at last , Ellen ; the height of the quarrel came .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: It was bound to come . I knew it would come , Matt .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: He was a foolish man to put shame on me after all I did for the land .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: You had too much thought for the land .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: I had in troth . The others went when there was less to be done . They could not stand him . Even the girls stole away .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: There was the high spirit in the whole of you .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: I showed it to him . “ Stop , ” said I ; “ no more , or I fling lands and house and everything aside . ”

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: You said that .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Ay . “ Your other children went for less , ” said I ; “ do you think there 's no blood in me at all ? ”

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: What happened then ?

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: “ I 'm your last son , ” I said ; “ keep your land and your twenty years ’ purchase . I 'm with the others ; and it 's poor your land will leave you , and you without a son to bring down your name . A bit of land , a house , ” said I ; “ do you think these will keep me here ? ”

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: I knew they could not keep you here , Matt . You have broken from them at last ; and now the world is before us . Think of all that is before us — the sea , and the ships , the strange life , and the great cities .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Ay — there before us — if we like .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: Surely we like .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: I was always shy of crowds . I 'm simple , after all , Ellen , and have no thought beyond the land .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: You said that house and land could not keep you . You told him you were going as your brothers went .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: And I felt I was going . I frightened him . He 'll be glad to see me back . It will be long before he treats me that way again .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: suddenlyMatt !

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: What is it , Ellen ?

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: I do n't know — I was upset — thinking of the quarrelputting her hands on his shouldersMy poor Matt . It was about me you quarrelled .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Ay , he spoke against you . I could n't put up with that .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: He does not know your high spirit . He does not know your strength .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Ellen , it 's no shame for a man to have harsh words said to him when it 's about a woman like you .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: Let nothing come between us now . I saw you in the winter making drains and ditches , and it wet . It 's a poor story , the life of a man on the land .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: I had too much thought for the land .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: You had . Have thought for me now . There is no one in fair or market but would notice me . I was never a favourite . I lived to myself . I did not give my love about . You have never offered me anything . In the song a man offers towns to his sweetheart . You can offer me the sights of great towns , and the fine manners , and the fine life .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Ellen !He draws a little awayIt 's not me that could offer the like of that . I never had anything to my hand but a spade .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: Your brothers — think of them .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: They all left some one behind them . I am the last of my name .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: Why should that keep you back ?

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: His name is something to a man . Could you hear of your own name melting away without unease ? And you are a woman . A man feels it more .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: I do not understand men . Will you go back to your father 's house after he shaming you out of it ?

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: He 'll be glad to see me back . He 'll never cast it up to me that I went .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: Matt , your father said words against me . Will you go to him and take his hand after that ?

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: It was little he said against you . It was against your father he spoke .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: sinking down on a chair , and putting hands before her faceMy God ! After all my waiting , you talk like that .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: going to herEllen , Ellen , tell me what I can do for you ? There 's land and houses to be had here . Father will let me have my own way after this .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: rising , with angerWhat does it matter to me whether he lets you have your own way or not ? Do you think I could go into a farmer 's house ?

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Ellen !

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: It 's a bad hand I 'd make of a farmer 's house . I 'm not the sort to be in one . I 'm not like Sally .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: getting angryDo n't be talking that way , Ellen Douras .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: with great vehemenceI must be talking like this . If you take me , you will have to go from your father 's house . I always knew it . You ought to know it now , Matt Cosgar .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: You did n't know it always . And you have let some one come between us when you talk like that .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: I 'm not one to be listening to what people say about you . Nor do I be talking in the markets about you .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: I suppose not . You would n't have people think you gave any thought to me ; I 'm not good enough for you . The people you know are better .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: You are foolish to be talking like that . You are foolish , I say .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: I know I am foolish . Fit only to be working in drains and ditches in the winter . That 's what you think .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: Maybe it is .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Ellen Douras ! Ellen Douras ! A farmer 's roof will be high enough for you some day .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: May I never see the day . Go back , go back . Make it up with your father . Your father will be glad of a labourer .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Maybe you wo n't be glad if I go back ; thinking on what you 've said .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: I said too much . We do n't know each other at all . Go back . You have made your choice . She goes up to room left .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Very well , then . God above , am I to be treated everywhere like a heifer strayed into a patch of oats ? Neither man nor woman will make me put up with this any longer .Going to doorWhen Ellen Douras wants me , she knows the place to send to .He stands at door . There is no sound from room . Going back he speaks loudlyI 'll be waiting two days or three days to hear from Ellen Douras . There is no sound . Matt goes out . The room door is thrown open , and Ellen comes down .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: furiouslyTwo days or three days he 'll wait for me . As if I 'd go into Murtagh Cosgar 's house . As if I 'd go into any farmer 's house . As if I 'd get married at all , and the world before me . Two days or three days you 'll wait . Maybe it 's lonesome , weary years you 'll be waiting , Matt Cosgar .

sp.speaker: ACT III
sp.p: Interior of Murtagh Cosgar 's . It is towards sunset . Murtagh Cosgar is standing before the door looking out . Martin Douras is sitting at the fire in an armchair .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: It 's getting late , Murtagh Cosgar .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Ay , it 's getting late .

lg.l: It 's time for me to be going home . I should be seeing

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Stay where you are .Turning roundWe 're two old men , as you say . We should keep each other 's company for a bit .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: I should be going home to see Ellen .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: If she 's going , you can n't stay her . Let you keep here .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: She 'll be wondering what happened to me .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Divil a bit it will trouble her . You 're going to the fair anyway ?

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: I have no heart to be going into a fair .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: It 's myself used to have the great heart . Driving in on my own side-car , and looking down on the crowd of them . It 's twenty years since I took a sup of drink . Oh , we 'll have drinking to-morrow that will soften the oul ’ skin of you . You 'll be singing songs about the Trojans to charm every baste in the fair .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: We 're both old men , Murtagh Cosgar .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: And is there any reason in your scholarship why oul ’ men should be dry men ? Answer me that !

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: I wo n't answer you at all , Murtagh Cosgar . There 's no use in talking to you .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Put it down on a piece of paper that oul ’ men should have light hearts when their care is gone from them . They should be like —

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: There 's nothing in the world like men with their rearing gone from them , and they old . Sally comes to the door . She enters stealthily .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Ha , here 's one of the clutch home . Well , did you see that brother of yours ?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: I did . He 'll be home soon , father .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: What 's that you say ? Were you talking to him ? Did he say he 'd be home ?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: I heard him say it , father .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: God bless you for the news , Sally .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: How could he go and he the last of them ? Sure it would be against nature . Where did you see him , Sally ?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: At Martin Douras 's , father .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: It 's that Ellen Douras that 's putting him up to all this . Do n't you be said by her , Sally .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: No , father .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: You 're a good girl , and if you have n't wit , you have sense . He 'll be home soon , did you say ?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: He was coming home . He went round the long way , I 'm thinking . Ellen Douras was vexed with him , father . She is n't going either , Matt says , but I 'm thinking that you might as well try to keep a corncrake in the meadow for a whole winter , as to try to keep Ellen Douras in Aughnalee .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Make the place tidy for him to come into . He 'll have no harsh words from me .He goes up to the room

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Father 's surely getting ould .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: sitting downHe 's gone up to rest himself , God help him . Sally , a stor , I 'm that fluttered , I dread going into my own house .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: I 'll get ready now , and let you have a good supper before you go to the fair .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: Sit down near me , and let me hear everything , Sally . Was it Matt that told you , or were you talking to Ellen herself ?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: O , indeed , I had a talk with Ellen , but she wo n't give much of her mind away . It was Matt that was telling me . “ Indeed she 's not going , ” said he , “ and a smart young fellow like myself thinking of her . Ellen is too full of notions . ” Here 's Matt himself . Father wo n't have a word to say to him . He 's getting mild as he 's getting ould , and maybe it 's a fortune he 'll be leaving to myself . Matt comes to the door . He enters .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Where is he ? He 's not gone to the fair so early ?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: He 's in the room .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Were you talking to him at all ? Were you telling him you saw myself ?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: I was telling him that you were coming back .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: How did he take it ?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Very quiet . God help us all ; I think father 's losing his spirit .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: going to MartinWell , you see I 've come back , Martin .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: Ay , you 're a good lad . I always said you were a good lad .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: How did father take it , Martin ?

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: Quietly , quietly . You saw Ellen ?

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Ay , I saw EllengloomilyShe should n't talk the way she talks , Martin . What she said keeps coming into my mind , and I 'm troubled . God knows I 've trouble enough on my head .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: eagerlyWhat did she say , Matt Cosgar ?

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: It was n't what she said . She has that school in her mind , I know .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: And is there anything to keep her here , Matt Cosgar ?

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: I do n't know that she thinks much of me now . We had a few words , but there 's nothing in the world I put above Ellen Douras .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: I should be going to her .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Wait a bit , and I 'll be going with you . Wait a bit . Let us talk it over . She would n't go from you , and you old .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: God forgive my age , if it would keep her here . Would I have my Ellen drawing turf , or minding a cow , or feeding pigs ?

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: I 'm fond of her , Martin . She could n't go , and I so fond of her . What am I doing here ? I should be making it up with her . What good will anything be if Ellen Douras goes ?He turns to the door , then stopsI came to settle with him . I must n't be running about like a frightened child . The room door opens , and Murtagh Cosgar is seen . Sally has hung a pot over the fire , and is cleaning the dishes at the dresser .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: at the room doorSally , it 's time to be putting on the meal . If you have any cabbage left , put it through the meal .To MattYou put the thong in the harness ?

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: I didpauseWell , I 've come back to you .

sp.speaker: MURTGAH COSGAR
sp.p: You 're welcome . We were making ready for the fair .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: I 'll be going out again before nightfall .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: I 'll not be wanting you here , or at the fair .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: sullenlyThere 's no good talking to me like that .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: You said , “ I 've come back , ” and I said , “ you 're welcome . ” You said , “ I 'm going out again , ” and I said , “ I 'll not be wanting you . ”

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Father , have you no feeling for me at all ?

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Sure the wild raven on the tree has thought for her young .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Ay , but do you feel for me , and I standing here , trying to talk to you ?

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: You 're my son , and so I feel sorry for you ; and you beginning to know your own foolishness .He turns to SallyI 'm not taking the pigs . Put a fresh bedding under them to-night .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: I will , father .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Be up early , and let the cows along the road , or they 'll be breaking into the young meadow .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: I 'll do that , too .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Be sure to keep enough fresh milk for the young calf .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: I 'll be sure to do it , father . She goes out . Martin takes out his paper , and begins to read it again .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: turning on MurtagBefore I go out again there 's something I want settled .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: What is it you want ?

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Would you have me go , or would you have me stay ?

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Do n't be talking of going or staying , and you the last of them .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: But I will be talking of it . You must treat me differently if you want me to stay . You must treat me differently to the way you treat Sally .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: You were always treated differently , Matt . In no house that ever I remember was there a boy treated as well as you are treated here .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: The houses that you remember are different from the houses that are now . Will you have me go , or will you have me stay ?

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: You 're very threatening . I 'd have you stay . For the sake of the name , I 'd have you stay .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Let us take hands on it , then .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Wait , we 'll see what you want first .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: You have no feeling . I 'd go out of this house , only I want to give you a chance .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Stop . We can have kindness in this . We need n't be beating each other down , like men at a fair .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: We 're not men at a fair . May God keep the kindness in our hearts .

lg.l: Do n't be going , Martin Douras .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Do n't be going yet . I 'll be with you , when you 're going . Martin sits down .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: to MattYou 'll be getting married , I suppose , if you stay ?

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Maybe I will .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: bitterlyIn the houses that are now , the young marry where they have a mind to . It 's their own business , they say .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Maybe it is their own business . I 'm going to marry Ellen Douras , if she 'll have me .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Ellen is a good girl , and clever , I 'm told . But I would not have you deal before you go into the fair .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: I 'm going to marry Ellen Douras .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Her father is here , and we can settle it now . What fortune will you be giving Ellen , Martin ? That 100 pounds that was saved while you were in Maryborough gaol ? Martin shakes his head .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: stubbornlyI 'm going to marry Ellen Douras , with or without a fortune .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: passionatelyBoy , your father built this house . He got these lands together . He has a right to see that you and your generations are in the way of keeping them together .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: I 'll marry Ellen Douras , with or without a fortune .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Marry her , then . Marry Ellen Douras .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Now , Martin , we must n't let an hour pass without going to her .He takes Martin 's arm , and they go to the door

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Marry Ellen Douras , I bid you . Break what I have built , scatter what I have put together . That is what all the young will be doing , Ellen Douras comes to the door as Matt and Martin reach it .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Ellen ! She shrinks back .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: It 's my father I came to speak to .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: going to the door , and drawing the bolt from the half-doorWhen you come to my house , Ellen Douras , you are welcome within . Ellen comes in ,

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: It 's right that I should speak to you all . Matt Cosgar , I am going from here .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Ellen , Ellen , do n't be saying that . Do n't be thinking of the few words between us . It 's all over now . Father agrees to us marrying . Speak , father , and let her hear yourself say it .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: I can n't go into a farmer 's house .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: You said that out of passion . Do n't keep your mind on it any longer .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: It 's true , it 's true . I can n't go into a farmer 's house . This place is strange to me .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: How can you talk like that ? I 'm always thinking of you .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: I 've stayed here long enough . I want my own way ; I want to know the world .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: If you go , how will I be living , day after day ? The heart will be gone out of me .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: You 'll be owning the land , Matt Cosgar .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: passionatelyI 've worked on the land all my days . Do n't talk to me about it now . Ellen goes to Martin . Murtagh goes up to the door , and then turns and speaks .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Listen to me , Matt Cosgar ; and you listen too , Ellen Douras . It 's a new house you want maybe . This house was built for me and my generations ; but I 'll build a new house for you both . It 's hard for a man to part with his land before the hour of his death ; and it 's hard for a man to break his lands ; but I 'll break them , and give a share of land to you .

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: You were never friendly to me ; but you have the high spirit , and you deserve a better daughter than I would make . The land and house you offer would be a drag on me .She goes to the door

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Ellen , what he offers is nothing , after all ; but I care for you . Sure you wo n't go from me like that ?

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: Oh , can n't you let me go ? I care for you as much as I care for any one . But it 's my freedom I want .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Then you 're going surely ?

sp.speaker: ELLEN
sp.p: I am . Good-bye . She goes out , Martin follows her . Matt stands dazed . Murtagh closes the door , then goes and takes Matt 's arm , and brings him down .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Be a man . We offered her everything , and she went . There 's no knowing what the like of her wants . The men will be in soon , and we 'll drink to the new ownership .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Oh , what 's the good in talking about that now ? If Ellen was here , we might be talking about it .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: To-morrow you and me might go together . Ay , the bog behind the meadow is well drained by this , and we might put the plough over it . There will be a fine , deep soil in it , I 'm thinking . Do n't look that way , Matt , my son .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: When I meet Ellen Douras again , it 's not a farmer 's house I 'll be offering her , nor life in a country place .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: No one could care for you as I care for you . I know the blood between us , and I know the thoughts I had as I saw each of you grow up . Matt moves to the door .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Where are you going ?

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: To see the boys that are going away .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Wait till the fall and I 'll give you money to go and come back . Farrell Kavanagh often goes to America . You could go with him .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: I 'll go by myself , unless Ellen Douras comes now . The creamery owes me money for the carting , and I 'll get it .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Then go . Good-bye to you , Matt Cosgar .

sp.speaker: MATT
sp.p: Good-bye to you . He goes out . Murtagh stands , then moves about vaguely

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: The floor swept , the hearth tidied . It 's a queer end to it all . Twenty years I bid them offer . Twenty years , twenty years ! Martin comes back .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: The men will be coming back .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: I suppose they will .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: You 're a queer fellow , Martin Douras . You went to gaol for some meeting .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: Ay .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Them was the stirring times . I can n't help but think of you in gaol , and by yourself . What brings you back now ?

lg.l: Ellen told me to go back . I should say something to

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: He went out as you came in .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: I 'll go in when the house is quiet . I 'll have a few prayers to be saying this night .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: I 'm going to the fair .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: I wo n't be going to the fair .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Why wo n't you be going to the fair ? Did n't you ask me for a lift ? You 'll be going with me .

lg.l: I wo n't be going , and do n't be overbearing me now ,

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: You will be going to the fair , if it was only to be showing that , seemly face of yours .Going to the door , he calls“ Sally ! ”He turns to Martin DourasI 've a daughter still , Martin Douras .

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: You have , and I have a son .

lg.l: What would you say to a match between them , Martin

sp.speaker: MARTIN DOURAS
sp.p: I have nothing to say again it .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Then a match it will be . Sally comes in from yard .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: If you fed that baste on honey , she 'd turn on you . Cabbage I gave her and got into trouble for it , and now she 's gone and trampled the bad potatoes till they 're hardly worth the boiling . I 'll put the bush in the gap when I 'm going out again , father .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Ay . Is that Cornelius Douras that 's coming up the path ?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: O faith it is . I 'll get him to give me a hand with the trough . Cornelius comes in .

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: Well , Murtagh Cosgar , a great and memorial day is ended . May you live long to enjoy the fruits of it . Twenty years on the first term , and the land is ours and our children 's . I met the men .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Ours and our children 's , ay . We 've been making a match between yourself and Sally .

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: Between me and Sally ?

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: Between Cornelius and myself ?

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: Ay , shake hands on it now .

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: And tell me one thing , Murtagh Cosgar . Is it true that Matt 's going to America , and that Ellen will wait for him for a year at the school ? I met them together , and they told me that .

sp.speaker: MURTAGH COSGAR
sp.p: What they say is true , I 'm sure . The land is yours and your children 's .

sp.speaker: SALLY
sp.p: wiping her hands in her apronO Cornelius .

sp.speaker: CORNELIUS
sp.p: Are n't they foolish to be going away like that , father , and we at the mouth of the good times ? The men will be coming in soon , and you might say a few words .Martin shakes his headIndeed you might , father ; they 'll expect it of you .Martin shakes his head . Murtagh and Sally try to restrain him“ Men of Ballykillduff , ” you might say , “ stay on the land , and you 'll be saved body and soul ; you 'll be saved in the man and in the nation . The nation , men of Ballykillduff , do you ever think of it at all ? Do you ever think of the Irish nation that is waiting all this time to be born ? ” He becomes more excited ; he is seen to be struggling with words .

sp.speaker: END OF PLAY
sp.p: THE LAND was first produced at the Abbey Theater , Dublin , in June , 1905 , by The Irish National Theater Society , under the direction of W. G . Fay , with the following cast :—

sp.speaker: THOMAS MUSKERRY
sp.p: CHARACTERS

sp.speaker: THOMAS MUSKERRY The Master of Garrisowen Workhouse

lg.l: FELIX TOURNOUR The Porter at Workhouse Lodge
CHRISTY CLARKE A Boy reared in the Workhouse

div.stage: SCENE : Garrisowen , a town in the Irish Midlands .

div.head: ACT FIRST

stage.stage: The Master 's office in Garrisowen Workhouse . It is partly an office , partly a living room . To the right is a door opening on corridor , and in the back , left , a door leading to the Master 's apartments . There is an iron stove down from back and towards right , and a big grandfather 's clock back towards door of apartments . A basket arm chair down from stove , and a wooden chair beside it . There is a desk against wall , left , and an office stool before it . Down from this desk a table on which is a closed desk . On table are books , papers , and files . On a wooden chair beside the arm chair is a heap of newspapers and periodicals . There is a rack beside corridor door , and on rack a shawl , an old coat , a hat , and a bunch of big keys . In the corner , right , is a little cabinet , and on it a small mirror . Above door of apartments a picture of Daniel O'Connell . The grandfather 's clock is ticking audibly . It is 8. 45 p. m . The gas over desk is lighted .

Christy Clarke , a youth of about seventeen , is seated in the armchair reading a periodical . His clothes are threadbare , but brushed and clean . He looks studious , and has intellectual possibilities . The clock ticks on , the boy reads , but with little attention . At the corridor door there is a knocking . Christy Clarke turns slightly . The door opens , and a tall man in the ugly dress of a pauper is seen . The man is Felix Tournour . He carries in a bucket of coal . He performs this action like one who has acquired the habit of work under an overseer . He is an ugly figure in his pauper dress . His scanty beard is coal black . He has a wide mouth and discoloured teeth . His forehead is narrow and bony . He is about forty-five .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: in a harsh voice , after looking aroundIs he not back yet ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: without stirringIs who not back yet ?

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: The master I 'm talking about . I do n't know where he does be going those evenings . He shovels coal into the stove .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: And what is it to you where he does be going ?

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: Do n't talk to me like that , young fellow . You 're poorhouse rearing , even though you are a pet . Will he be sitting up here to-night , do you know ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: What 's that to you whether he will or not ?

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: If he 's sitting up late he 'll want more coal to his fire .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: Well , the abstracts will have to be finished to-night .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: Then he will be staying up . He goes out for a walk in the evenings now , and I do n't know where he does be going .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: He goes out for a walk in the country .Tournour makes a leer of contemptDo you never go for a walk in the country , Felix Tournour ?

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: They used to take me out for walks when I was a little fellow , but they never got me out into the country since .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: I suppose , now that you 're in the porter 's lodge , you watch every one that goes up and down the road ?

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: It gratifies me to do so — would you believe that now ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: You know a lot , Felix Tournour .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: We 're told to advance in knowledge , young fellow . How long is Tom Muskerry the Master of Garrisowen Workhouse ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: Thirty years this spring .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: Twenty-nine years .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: He 's here thirty years according to the books .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: Twenty-nine years .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: Thirty years .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: Twenty-nine years . I was born in the workhouse , and I mind when the Master came in to it . Whist now , here he is , and time for him . He falls into an officious manner . He closes up the stove and puts bucket away . Then he goes over to desk , and , with his foot on the rung of the office stool , he turns the gas on full . Christy Clarke gets out of armchair , and begins to arrange the periodicals that are on wooden chair . The corridor door opens . The man who appears is not the Master , however . He is the blind piper , Myles Gorman , who is dressed in the pauper garb . Myles Gorman is a Gael of the West of Ireland , with a face full of intellectual vigour . He is about sixty , and carries himself with energy . His face is pale and he has a fringe of a white beard . The eye-balls in his head are contracted , but it is evident he has some vestiges of sight . Before the others are aware who he is , he has advanced into the room . He stands there now turning the attentive face of the blind .

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: Mister Muskerry ! Are you there , Mister Muskerry ?

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: What do you want , my oul ’ fellow ?

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: with a puzzled lookWell , now , I 've a favour to ask of your honour .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: Be off out of this to your ward .

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: Is that Mister Muskerry ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: Mister Muskerry is n't here .

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: And who am I talking to ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: You are talking to Felix Tournour .

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: Felix Tournour ! Ay , ay . Good night , Felix Tournour . When will the Master be back ?

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: coming to himNot till you 're out of this , and back in your ward .

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: Was n't there a boy speaking to me ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: Yesspeaking as if to a deaf manThe Master will be going the rounds in a while , and you can speak to him in the ward .

sp.speaker: GORMAN I 've a favour to ask the Master , and I do n't want to ask it
sp.p: before the others .To ChristyWill the Master be here soon , a vick vig ?6

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: taking him by the shouldersHere , now , come on , this is your way out . He turns Gorman to the door . As he is putting him out Thomas Muskerry enters

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: This oul ’ fellow came into the office , and I was leading him back into his ward .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Leave the man alone . Tournour retreats to the stove and takes up the bucket ; after a look behind he goes out and closes the corridor door . Christy Clarke takes the periodicals over to table and sits down . Myles Gorman has been eager and attentive . Thomas Muskerry stands with his back to the stove . He is over sixty . He is a large man , fleshy in face and figure , sanguine and benevolent in disposition . He has the looks and movements of one in authority . His hair is white and long ; his silver beard is trimmed . His clothes are loosely fitting . He wears no overcoat , but has a white knitted muffler round his neck . He has on a black , broad-brimmed hat , and carries a walking-stick .

div.stage: Footnote 6 : A mhic bhig , my little son .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Well , my good man ?

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: I 'm here to ask a favour from you , Master .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: You should proffer your request when I 'm in the ward . However , I 'm ready to give you my attention .

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: I 'm a blinded man , Master , and when you 're in the ward I can n't get you by yourself conveniently . I can n't come up to you like the other oul ’ men and speak to you private like .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Well , now , what can I do for you ?

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: eagerlyThey tell me that to-morrow 's the market-day , and I thought that you might give me a pass , and let me go out about the town .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: We 'll consider it , Gorman .

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: Master , let me out in the town on the market-day .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: We could n't let you out to play your pipes through the town .

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: I 'm not thinking of the music at all , Master , but to be out in the day and to feel the throng moving about , and to be talking to the men that do be on the roads .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: We 'll consider it , Gorman .He takes off muffler , and puts it on back of armchair

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: Well , I 'm very much obliged to your honour . Good night to you , Master .He passes Muskerry and goes towards the door . Muskerry has been regarding him

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Tell me this , Gorman , were you always on the roads ?

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: I was driving cattle , and I was dealing in horses . Then I took up with an oul ’ man , and he taught me the pipes . I 'm playing the pipes ever since , and that 's thirty years ago . Well , the eyes began to wither up on me , and now I 've only a stim of sight . I 'm a blinded man from this out , Master .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: And what will you do ?

lg.l: Oh , sure the roads of Ireland are before me when I leave this ;
I 'll be playing my bit of music .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Tell me ; have you any family yourself ?

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: Ne'er a chick nor child belonging to me . Ne'er a woman lay by me . I went the road by myself . Will you think of what I asked you , Master ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I 'll consider it .

lg.l: Good night to your honour . Remember my name , Master — Gorman ,

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Now , Christy Clarke , I consider that the man gone out is a very exceptional man .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: Is it Myles Gorman ?

lg.l: Yes . I 'd even say that , considering his station in life ,
Myles Gorman is a very superior man .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: They say he 's not a good musician .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: And maybe he 's not . I consider , however , that there 's great intelligence in his face . He stands before you , and you feel that he has the life of a young colt , and then you 're bound to think that , in spite of the fact that he 's blind and a wanderer , the man has not wasted his life .Muskerry settles himself in the armchair

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: Will you give leave for to-morrow ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: No , Christy , I will not .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: Why not , Mister Muskerry ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: That man would break bounds and stay away .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: Do you think he would ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: He 'd fly off , like the woodquest flying away from the tame pigeons .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: He and his brother had a farm between them . His brother was married , and one day the brother told Myles to go to Dublin to see a comrade of his who was sick . Myles was home in a week , and when he came back he found that his brother had sold the place and was gone out of the country .

lg.l: His brother did wrong , but he did n't do so much wrong to

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: How is that , Mister Muskerry ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: He sent Myles Gorman to his own life . He 's a man who went his own way always ; a man who never had any family nor any affairs ; a man far different from me , Christy Clarke . I was always in the middle of affairs . Then , too , I busied myself about other people . It was for the best , I think ; but that 's finished . On the desk under your hand is a letter , and I want you to bring it to me .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: going through papers idly“ I am much obliged for your favour — ”

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: That 's not it .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: reading another letter“ I am about to add to the obligations under which I stand to you , by recommending to your notice my grandson , Albert Crilly — ”

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: That 's the letter . It 's the last of its kind . Bring it to me .Christy Clarke brings over the letterThere comes a turn in the blood and a turn in the mind , Christy . This while back I 've been going out to the country instead of into the town , and coming back here in the evenings I 've seen the workhouse with the big wall around it , and the big gate going into it , and I 've said to myself that Thomas Muskerry ought to be as secure and contented here as if he was in his own castle .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: And so you ought , Mister Muskerry .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Look round at the office , Christy . I 've made it as fit for me as the nest for the wren . I 'll spend a few more years here , and then I 'll go out on pension . I wo n't live in the town , I 've seen a place in the country I 'd like , and the people will be leaving it in a year or two .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: Where is it , Mister Muskerry ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I 'll say no more about it now , but it 's not far from this , and its near the place , where I was reared .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: And so you 'll go back to your own place ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: As Oliver Goldsmith my fellow county man , and I might almost say , my fellow parishioner , says — What 's this the lines are about the hare , Christy ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: “ And like the Hare whom Hounds and Horns pursue Pants to the place from whence at first he flew . ”

lg.l: Aye . “ And like the Hare whom Hounds and Horns pursue ” —

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: You were n't on the rounds yet ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: startledWould you believe it , now , it was nearly passing my mind to go on the rounds ?He rises , putting the letter in his pocketWhere 's that fellow , Albert Crilly ? He was to have been in here to give me a hand with the abstracts . Christy Clarke , go down to Miss Coghlan 's and get me two novelettes . Bring me up two nice love stories , and be here when I come back . Christy Clarke takes his cap off rack and goes out . Thomas Muskerry puts on his scarf , goes to the rack and takes down the bunch of keys . As he is going out Felix Tournour enters with a bucket of coal . He carries it over to the stove .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Now , Tournour , sweep up this place . Thomas Muskerry goes out by corridor door . Felix Tournour takes brush from under desk , left , and begins to sweep in the direction of corridor door .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: Sweeping , sweeping ! I 'll run out of the house some day on account of the work I 've to do for Master Thomas Muskerry .He leans on his brush in front of stoveI know why you 're going for walks in the country , my oul ’ cod . There 's them in town that you 've got enough of . You do n't want to go bail for Madam Daughter , nor for Count Crofton Crilly , your son-in-law , nor for the Masters and Mistresses ; all right , my oul ’ cod-fish . That I may see them laying you out on the flags of Hell .He puts the brush standing upright , and speaks to it“ The Devil went out for a ramble at night , Through Garrisowen Union to see every sight . The ould men were dreaming of meat to come near them , And the Devil cocked ears at the words for to hear them . ‘ Twice a year we get meat , ’ said the toothless oul ’ men , ‘ Oh , Lord send the meat wo n't be too tough again . ’ To clear away dishes Mick Fogarty goes , May the Devil burn the nails off his toes . Deep dreaming that night of fast days before , Sagging the walls with the pull of his snore , In his chamber above Thomas Muskerry lay snug , When the Devil this summons roared in his lug — ” The door of the Master 's apartments is opened and Albert Crilly enters . Albert Crilly is a young man , who might be a bank clerk or a medical student . He is something of a dude , but has a certain insight and wit .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: lighting a cigaretteIs the grandparent here , Tournour ?

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: He 's gone on the rounds , Mister Albert .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: What time was he up this morning ?

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: He was late enough . He was n't up in time to come to Mass with us .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: The old man will get into trouble .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: If the nuns hear about it .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: He 'll have to give the whole thing up soon .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: He 's well off that can get somebody else to do the work for him .He continues to sweep towards corridor

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: Tournour , you 're a damned clever fellow . I heard a piece of yours yesterday that I thought was damned good .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: Was it a rhyme ?

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: It was something called “ The Devil 's Rambles . ”

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: taking a step towards himDo n't let the boss hear , and I 'll tell it to you , Mr. Albert .He holds the brush in his hands and is about to begin the recitation when Crofton Crilly enters from the Master 's apartments . Crofton Crilly has a presentable appearance . He is big and well made , has a fair beard and blue eyes . A pipe is always in his mouth . He is a loiterer , a talker , a listener

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Are you going to finish the abstracts to-night , Albert ?

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: I believe I am . Go on with “ The Devil 's Rambles , ” Tournour .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: I heard it in Keegan 's . It 's damn good .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: I do n't like saying it before Mister Crilly .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: with easy contemptGo on with it , man ; I 'll leave a pint in Keegan 's for you .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: Well , you might n't like it .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Have done talking and go on with it .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: reciting— “ In his chamber above — a — a person lay snug , When the Devil this summons roared in his lug — ‘ Get up , ’ said the Devil , ‘ and swear you 'll be true , And the oath of allegiance I 'll tender anew . You 'll have pork , veal , and lamb , mutton-chops , fowl and fish , Cabbage and carrots and leeks as you wish . No fast days to you will make visitation , For your sake the town will have dispensation . Long days you will have , without envy or strife , And when you depart you 'll find the same life , And in the next world you 'll have your will and your sway , With a Poorhouse to govern all your own way , And I 'll promise you this ; to keep up your state , You 'll have Felix Tournour to watch at the gate . ’ ”

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: That 's damn good . I must get a copy of the whole of it to show at Keegan 's . Tournour has swept as far as the corridor door . He opens it and sweeps down the passage . He goes out and closes door .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: That 's a damn clever fellow .He becomes anxious , as with a troubled recollection . He goes to the little cabinet , opens it , and takes out a bottle of whisky and a glass . He pours some whisky into the glass , and remains looking at himself in the mirror . He smooths his beard . He goes to the arm chair with the glass of whisky , the anxious expression still on his faceThis is a cursed town .He drinks

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: Every town in Ireland is a cursed town .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: But this is an extraordinarily cursed town . Everybody 's in debt to everybody else . I do n't know what 's to be done . Now , imagine that fellow , James Covey , failing in business and getting clear out of the town .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: Covey seems to have done it well .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: God knows how many he has stuck .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: Well , he did n't stick the Crillys for anything .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
