sp.p: Albert , you do n't know how these financial things work out . Do you think would his brother settle ?

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: Settle with whom ?

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Well ... with any of the ... any of the people that have ... I do n't know . It 's a cursed town . If I had joined the police at your age , I 'd have a pension by this , and I might n't care for any of them .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: I wish I had a job and I 'd wait on the pension .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Oh , you 'll be all right . The grandfather is seeing about your job .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: If the grandparent gets me that job I 'll want two new suits at least .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: ‘ Pon my soul , Albert , I do n't know what 's to be done .His mind wanders offI suppose the abstracts have to go out in the morning .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: They have . And damn all the old man has done to them .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: The Guardians hear that he 's late in the mornings , Albert , and some of them are beginning to question his fitness to check the stores .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: The old man ought to resign .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: I suppose he ought . I 'm not wishing for his resignation myself , Albert . You know your mother regards it as a settled thing that he should come and live with us .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: The mother and Anna are preparing for the event .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: How 's that , Albert ?

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: Mother has James Scollard in her eye for the new Master .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Right enough ! Scollard would get it , too , and then he would marry Anna .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: That 's the arrangement , I expect .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: It might n't be bad . Scollard might n't want Nancy 's money under that arrangement . Still I do n't like the idea of the old man living in the house .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: The mother would never think of letting him take himself and his pension anywhere else .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: I do n't think she would .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: I would n't be surprised if he did go somewhere else . I hear he often goes up to that cottage in Stradrina .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: What cottage , Albert ?

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: Briar Cottage . I hear he sits down there , and talks of coming to live in the place .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: warninglyAlbert , do n't clap hands behind the bird . Take my word , and say nothing about it .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: All right .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: We 'd have no comfort in the house if your mother 's mind was distracted . Mrs. Crilly enters from corridor . She is a woman of forty , dressed in a tailor-made costume . She has searching eyes . There is something of hysteria about her mouth . She has been good-looking .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Good night , Marianne .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY Are you finishing the abstracts , Albert ?
sp.p: ALBERT I 'm working at them . It 's a good job we did n't leave the old man much latitude for making mistakes .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: closing doorHe 'll have to resign .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Good God , Marianne .He rises

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Well . Let him be sent away without a pension . Of course , he can live with us the rest of his life and give us nothing for keeping him .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: I do n't know what 's in your mind at all , Marianne .He crosses over to the cabinet , opens it , and fills out another glass of whisky

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: Let the old man do what suits himself .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: coming back to stoveDo , Marianne . Let him do what suits himself . For the present .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: For pity 's sake put down that glass and listen to what I have to say .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: What 's the matter , Marianne ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: James Scollard came to me to-day , and he told me about the things that are noticed .... The nuns notice them , the Guardians notice them . He misses Mass . He is late on his rounds . He can n't check the stores that are coming into the house . He may get himself into such trouble that he 'll be dismissed with only an apology for a pension , or with no pension at all .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: I do n't know what 's to be done .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: If he could be got to resign now James Scollard would have a good chance of becoming Workhouse Master . He would marry Anna , and we would still have some hand in the affairs of the House .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Yes , yes . I think that Scollard could make a place for himself .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: The old man wo n't be anxious to retire .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Why should n't he retire when his time is up ?

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: Well , here he is what 's called a potentate . He wo n't care to come down and live over Crilly 's shop .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: And where else would he live in the name of God ?

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: He wo n't want to live with our crowd .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: What crowd ? The boys can be sent to school , you 'll be on your situation , and Anna will be away .She seats herself in the armchairI do n't know what Albert means when he says that the Master would not be content to live with us . It was always settled that he would come to us when his service was over . Albert , who has been going over the books , has met something that surprises him . He draws Crilly to the desk . The two go over the papers , puzzled and excited . Anna Crilly enters from corridor . She is a handsome girl of about nineteen or twenty , with a rich complexion dark hair and eyes . She is well dressed , and wears a cap of dark fur . She stands at the stove , behind her mother , holding her hands over the stove . Mrs. Crilly watches the pair at the desk .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: We can n't think of allowing a pension of fifty pounds a year to go out of our house . Where will we get money to send the boys to school ?

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Mother . Grandfather is going to live away from us .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Why do you repeat what Albert says ?

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: I did n't hear Albert say anything .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Then , what are you talking about ?

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Grandfather goes to Martin 's cottage nearly every evening , and stays there for hours . They 'll be leaving the place in a year or two , and Grandfather was saying that he would take the cottage when he retired from the Workhouse .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: When did you hear this ?

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: This evening . Delia Martin told me .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: And that 's the reason why he has kept away from us . He goes to strangers , and leaves us in black ignorance of his thought . Crilly and Albert are busy at desk .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Well , damn it all —

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: Here 's the voucher .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: God ! I do n't know what 's to be done .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: It 's a matter of fifty tons . Albert turns round deliberately , leaving his father going through the papers in desperate eagerness . Albert takes a cigarette from behind his ear , takes a match-box from his waistcoat pocket , and strikes a light . He goes towards door of apartments . Mrs. Crilly rises .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: his hand on the handle of doorWell so-long .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Where are you going ?

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: I 'm leaving you to talk it over with the old man . Mrs. Crilly looks from Albert to Crilly .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: The Master has let himself in for something serious , Marianne .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: It 's a matter of fifty pounds . The old man has let the Guardians pay for a hundred tons of coal when only fifty were delivered .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Is that so , Crofton ?

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: It looks like it , Marianne .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: There were fifty tons of coal already in stores , but the Governor did n't take them into account . That cute boy , James Covey , delivered fifty tons and charged for the hundred . The old man passed on the certificate , and the Guardians paid Covey . They helped him to his passage to America .He opens door and goes through

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: They will dismiss him — dismiss him without a pension .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Mother . If he gets the pension first , could they take it back from him ?

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: No . But they could make him pay back the fifty pounds in instalments .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Fifty pounds ! We can n't afford to lose fifty pounds .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Who would find out about the coal , father ?

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: The Guardians who take stock .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: And how would they know at this time whether there was a hundred or a hundred and fifty tons there at first ?

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: The business men amongst them would know . However , there wo n't be an inspection for some time .

lg.l: Suppose grandfather had got his pension and had left the
Workhouse , who would know about the coal ?

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: The new Workhouse Master .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: The new Workhouse Master —

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Marianne —

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: I think I 'll stay here and advise the old man .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: No . Go away .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: at door of apartmentsAfter all , I 'm one of the Guardians , and something might be done .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: You can do nothing . We can do nothing for him . Let him go to the strangers . Crilly goes out .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Anna !

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Yes , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: The Martins are not giving up their house for a year or two ?

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: No , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: If he resigns now his pension will be safe . There is nothing else against him .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: But some one will find out the difference in the coal .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: It 's the new Workhouse Master who will know that .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: hardeningBut he could not pass such a thing , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: abandoning a positionWell , after your grandfather gets his pension we could make some arrangement with the Guardians .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Yes , mother . Has n't grandfather a hundred pounds invested in the shop ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: It 's not a hundred pounds . Besides , it 's not an investment .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: with a certain resolution in her rich voiceMother . Is my money safe ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: We could give you the eighty pounds , Anna , but after that we would need all the help we could get from you .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Yes , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: again taking up a positionBut if we help James Scollard to the place .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: with determinationWhether Mr. Scollard gets the place or does not get the place , I 'll want my fortune , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Very well , Anna . If we could get him to come over . ...She sits in arm chairThere 's a lamb in Ginnell 's field ; you might call in to-morrow and ask them to prepare it for us .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Then grandfather is coming to dinner on Sunday ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: We must get him to come . Some one is coming up the passage . Anna 's hand is on handle of door . She holds it open . Thomas Muskerry stands there .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: pleased to see herWell , Nancy !

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Good night , grandpapa .He regards her with fondness

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Good night , father .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: This Nancy girl is looking remarkably well .He turns to Mrs. CrillyWell , ma'am , and how are you ? I 've written that letter for that rascally Albert . He leaves his stick on table and goes to desk . Mrs. Crilly watches him . Anna comes to her . Muskerry addresses an envelope with some labour . Mrs. Crilly notices a tress of Anna 's hair falling down . Anna kneels down beside her . She takes off Anna 's cap , settles up the hair , and puts the cap on again . Having addressed the envelope , Muskerry holds up a piece of wax to the gas . He seals the letter then holds it out .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Here 's the letter now , and maybe it 's the last thing I can do for any of ye .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: You are very good . Muskerry goes to them .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: In season and out of season I 've put myself at your service . I can do no more for ye . She takes the letter from him . His resentment is breaking down . He sits on chair beside armchair . He speaks in a reconciling tone .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: You 're looking well , Marianne ,

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: I 'm beginning to be well again .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: And the infant ? What age is he now ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Little Joseph is ten months old .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I dreamt of him last night . I thought Joseph became a bishop . He ought to be reared for the Church , Marianne . Well , well , I 've nothing more to do with that .He settles himself in the armchairDid Christy Clarke bring in the papers ?

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Christy Clarke has n't been here at all , grandpapa .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Stand here till I look at you Nancy .Anna comes left of stoveI would n't be surprised if you were the best-looking girl in the town , Nancy .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: without any coquettishnessAnna Crilly is riot going into competition with the others .She wraps the muffler round him , then kisses himGood night , grandpapa .She goes out by corridor door

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Thank you for the letter for Albert .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I think , Marianne , it 's the last thing I can do for you or yours .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Well , we can n't tell a bad story of you , and things are well with us .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I 'm glad to hear that . I was thinking of going to see you next week .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Come to dinner on Sunday . We are having a lamb .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: What sort is the lamb ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Oh , a very young lamb . Anna will make the dressing for you .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I 'll send round a bottle of wine . Perhaps we 'll be in the way of celebrating something for Albert .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Nancy was saying that you might like to stay a few days with us .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Stay a few days ! How could I do that , ma'am ?

lg.l: You could get somebody to look after the House . James
Scollard would do it , and you could stay out for a few days .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Well , indeed , I 'll do no such thing . What put it into your head to ask me this ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Nancy said —

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Let the girl speak for herself . What 's in your mind , woman ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Well , you 're not looking well .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I 'm as well as ever I was .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Others do not think so .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I suppose you heard I was late a few mornings . No matter for that . I 'm as well as ever I was . No more talk about it ; I 'm going on with the work .He rises and goes over to desk

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: I 'm sorry to say that no one else thinks as well of you as you do yourself .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Well , I 'll hear no more about it , and that 's enough about it . Why is n't Albert Crilly here ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Well , he was here , and he is coming back .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I 'll want him .He takes up a card left on the desk . He turns round and reads— “ You have let the Guardians pay for a hundred tons . James Covey delivered only fifty tons of coal . ” Who left this here ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: I suppose Albert left it for you .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY The impudent rascal . How dare he address himself like that
sp.p: to me ?He throws card on table

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Perhaps he found something out in the books .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: No matter whether he did or not , he 'll have to have respect when he addresses me . Anyway it 's a lie — a damn infernal lie . I was in the stores the other day , and there was eighty tons of coal still there . Certainly twenty tons had been taken out of it . The Provision Check Account will show .He takes up a book and turns round . He goes back some pages . He lets the book fall . He stands there helplessI suppose you all are right in your judgment of me . I 'm at my failing time . I 'll have to leave this without pension or prospect . They 'll send me away .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: They had nothing against you before this .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I was spoken of as the pattern for the officials of Ireland .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: If you resigned now —

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Before this comes out .He looks for helpMarianne , it would be like the blow to the struck ox if I lost my pension .

lg.l: If you managed to get the pension you could pay the
Guardians back in a lump sum .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: If I resigned now , where would I go to ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: It was always understood that you would stay with us .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: No , Marianne .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: You 'll have the place to yourself . The boys will be going to school , and Albert will be away , too . Anna and myself will look after you .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I could stay for a while .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Oh , well , if you have a better place to go —

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Remember what I said , Marianne . I 've worked for you and yours , in season and out of season . There should be no more claims on me .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: There are no more claims on you .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I 'm willing to leave in the shop what I put into the shop . Let Anna know that it will come to her from me . I 'll write to the Guardians to-night and I 'll send in my resignation . I venture to think that they 'll know their loss . Mrs. Crilly goes out quietly by corridor door .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: by himselfAnd I had made this place as fit for me as the nest for the wren . Was n't he glad to write that card , the impudent rascal , with his tongue in his cheek ? I 'll consider it again . I wo n't leave this place till it fits myself to leave it . Christy Clarice enters by corridor door with papers .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: They want me to resign from this place , Christy .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: You 're thirty years here ! Are n't you , Mister Muskerry ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Thirty years , thirty years . Ay , Christy , thirty years ; it 's a long time . And I 'm at my failing time . Perhaps I 'm not able to do any more . Day after day there would be troubles here , and I would n't be able to face them . And in the end I might lose my position . I 'm going to write out my resignation .He goes to the desk and writes . Christy is at table . Muskerry turns round after writing

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: No one that comes here can have the same heart for the poor that I had . I was earning in the year of the famine . I saw able men struggling to get the work that would bring them a handful of Indian meal . And I saw the little children waiting on the roads for relief .He turns back and goes on with letter . Suddenly a bell in the House begins to tollWhat 's that for , Christy ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: Malachi O'Rourk , the Prince , as they called him , is dead .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Aye , I gave orders to toll him when he died . He was an estated gentleman , and songs were made about his family . People used to annoy him , but he 's gone from them now . Bring me a little whisky , Christy . Christy goes to Cabinet . Muskerry follows him .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: There 's none in the bottle , Mister Muskerry .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: bitterlyNo , I suppose not . And is that rascal , Albert Crilly , coming back ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: He 's coming , Mister Muskerry . I left the novelette on the table . Miss Coghlan says it 's a nice love story . “ The Heart of Angelina , ” it is called .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I have n't the heart to read . The bell continues to toll . Christy goes to door .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: Good night , Mister Muskerry .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Good night , Christy . Christy Clarke goes out through apartments . Thomas Muskerry is standing with hand on arm chair . The bell tolls .

stage.stage: In Crilly 's , a month later . The room is the parlour off the shop . A glass door , right , leads into the shop , and the fireplace is above this door . In the back , right , is a cupboard door . Back is a window looking on the street . A door , left , leads to other rooms . There is a table near shop door and a horse-hair sofa back , an armchair at fire , and two leather-covered chairs about . Conventional pictures on walls , and two certificates framed , showing that some one in the house has passed some Intermediate examinations .
It is the forenoon of an April day . Mrs. Crilly is seated on sofa , going through a heap of account books . Anna Crilly is at window . Crofton Crilly enters from the shop .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: It 's all right , Marianne .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: The Guardians insisted on appointing an outside person to take stock of the workhouse stores . It 's the new regulation , you know . Well , the job lay between young Dobbs and Albert , and Albert has got it . I do n't say but it was a near thing .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: I hope Albert will know what to do .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: He 'll want to watch the points . Where 's the Master ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: He 's in his room upstairs .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Was he not out this morning ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: He 's not dressed yet .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: He was more particular when he was in the workhouse .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: I know who those two children are now . They are the new gas-manager 's children .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: He 's a Scotchman .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: And married for the second time . Mother , Mrs. Dunne is going to the races . Such a sketch of a hat .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: It would be better for her if she stayed at home and looked after her business .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: She wo n't have much business to look after soon . That 's the third time her husband has come out of Farrell 's public-house .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: He 's drinking with the Dispensary Doctor . Companions ! They 're the curse of this town , Marianne .He sits down

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: She 's walked into a blind man , hat and all . He 's from the Workhouse .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: He 's the blind piper out of the workhouse , Myles Gorman .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: There 's no one within . You should go into the shop , Anna .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Yes , mother .She crossesJames Scollard is coming in , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Very well , Anna . Stay in the shop until Mary comes . Anna goes into the shop . Crilly moves about .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: You 're very uneasy .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Yes , I am uneasy , Marianne . There 's some presentment on me . Fifty pounds a year is a good pension for the old man . He 's a month out now . He ought to be getting an instalment . Anna comes in from shop .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Mother , the doctor 's daughter is in the shop .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: What does she want ?

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: imitating an accentSend up a pound of butter , two pounds of sugar , and a pound of tea .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: These people are paying nobody . But we can n't refuse her . I suppose we 'll have to send them up . Be very distant with her , Anna .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: I 've kept her waiting . Here 's a letter , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: taking letterWhen did it come , Anna ?

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: It 's just handed in . Anna goes out . Mrs. Crilly opens letter .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: It 's from the bank . They want me to call . What does the bank manager want with me , I wonder ?

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: I have something to tell you , Marianne . I 'll tell you in a while .He takes a turn up and down

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: What do you want to tell me ?

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Prepare your mind , Marianne .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: What is it ?

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: I owe you money , Marianne .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Money ! How do you owe me money ?

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: That cute boy , James Covey , who took in all the town —

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: risingCovey ! My God ! You backed a bill for him ?

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: I 'll make a clean breast of it . I did .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: with fear in her eyesHow much is it ?

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: walking away to windowI 'll come to that , Marianne .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Did any one back the bill with you ?

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: I obliged the fellow . No one backed the bill with me .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Does any one know of it ?

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: No , Marianne .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: The bank .... Tell me what happened .

lg.l: The bank manager sent for me when he came to the town after

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: We had four hundred pounds in the bank .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: We had , Marianne .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Tell me how much was the bill .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: There 's no use in beating about the bush . The bill was for three hundred pounds .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: And what has the bank done ?

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: I 'm sorry to say , Marianne , the bank has taken the money over from our account .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: You 've ruined us at last , Crofton Crilly .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: You should never forgive me , Marianne . I 'll go to America and begin life again .He turns to go out by shop

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: We have no money left .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: A hundred pounds , Marianne .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: That 's Anna 's money .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Scollard should be satisfied .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Anna insists on getting her money .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Very well , Marianne . I 'll leave it all to yourself . James Scollard comes in . Anna is behind him . Scollard has an account book in his hand .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: Good morning , Mrs. Crilly . Good morning , Mr. Crilly .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Good morning , Mr. Scollard . Crofton Crilly turns to go .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Do n't go , father .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: Do n't go , Mr. Crilly . I have something particular to say to yourself and Mrs. Crilly .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Sit down , Mr. Scollard . Anna brings chair , and Scollard sits center . Anna stands behind him . Mrs. Crilly sits left of him .

lg.l: I am here to propose for the hand of your daughter , Miss

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: We have nothing to say against your proposal , Mr. Scollard .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Wo n't you take something , James ?

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: No , thanks , Mr. Crilly . I never touch intoxicants . Crofton Crilly goes into shop .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: We could n't wish for a better match for Anna . But I feel bound to tell you , Mr. Scollard , that we have had a very severe loss in our business .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: What is it , mother ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: I do n't mind telling you . Mr. Crilly has made himself responsible for a bill on the bank .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: In whose interest , Mrs. Crilly ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: He backed a bill for James Covey . A bill for three hundred pounds .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Oh , mother !

lg.l: It 's a dead sure loss . I do n't know what we are to do ,

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: This is very bad , Mrs. Crilly . Crofton Crilly comes back from shop . He brings in a glass of whisky . He puts whisky on chimney-piece .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: The bank has taken over three hundred pounds from our account .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Perhaps Scollard —

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: What were you saying , Mr. Crilly ?

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Oh , I was just thinking — about a bill you know — If some one would go security for us at the bank —

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Father , what are you saying ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: It 's unnecessary to talk like that . In spite of your foolishness , we still have a balance at the bank .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: My portion comes to me from my grandmother .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: May I ask , Mrs. Crilly , is Miss Crilly 's portion safe ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: It is safe , Mr. Scollard .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: I have been definitely appointed Master of the Union , and I may say that Anna and myself are anxious to marry .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: It need n't be soon , Mr. Scollard .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: After Easter , Mrs. Crilly .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: But that 's very soon .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: I am anxious to settle down , Mrs. Crilly . I 'm on my way to a meeting of the Board of Guardians , but before I go I 'd like to have some more information about your loss .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Anna 's portion is not touched , but we could hardly afford to let the money go from us now .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: Is that so , Mrs. Crilly ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Three hundred pounds is a very severe loss .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: Very severe , indeed . Still , you understand , Mrs. Crilly , the difficulties of taking such a step as marriage without adequate provision .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Damn it all , man , Marianne and myself married without anything at all .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: bitterlyAnna wo n't be such a fool as her mother .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Well , Scollard has his position , and we helped him to it .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: I acknowledge that .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Is n't my portion eighty pounds , mother ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Yes , Anna . But I 'd like to tell Mr. Scollard that it would come as a strain on us to let the money go at once .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: I daresay , Mrs. Crilly .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: But , mother , would n't the money be safer with us ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Well , I leave the whole thing in the hands of Mr. Scollard .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: Anna and myself have been talking things over , Mrs. Crilly .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: And we do n't want to begin life in a poor way .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: We see the advantage of being always solvent , Mrs. Crilly .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: James has ambitions , and there 's no reason why he should n't venture for the post of Secretary of the County Council when old Mr. Dobbs retires .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: In a few years , Mrs. Crilly , when I had more official experience and some reputation .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Then he would have seven or eight hundred a year .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: As I said , a man like myself would want to be in a perfectly solvent position .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Besides , James has no money of his own .

lg.l: I never had the chance of putting money by — Family calls ,

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: And we do n't want to begin life in a poor way .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: You wo n't want the whole of the money . I 'll give you forty pounds now .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: And forty when the first child is born .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Oh , father , how can you say such a thing ?

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: I need only say this . Anna and myself were talking over affairs , and we came to the conclusion it would be best not to start with less than eighty pounds .He risesI have to go down to the Board Room now , for there is a meeting of the Guardians .He goes towards door

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Wo n't you take a glass ?

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: No , thanks , Mr. Crilly . I never touch stimulants . Good day to you all . He goes out . Crofton Crilly goes after him .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Anna , you wo n't be deprived of your money .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Then what 's the difficulty , mother ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Let half of the money remain with us for a while .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: But , mother , if I do n't get all my money , what security have I that what 's left will be good in six months or a year ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: I 'll watch the money for you , Anna .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: It 's hard to keep a hold on money in a town where business is going down .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Forty pounds will be given to you and forty pounds will be kept safe for you .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Forty pounds ! There 's not a small farmer comes into the shop but his daughter has more of a dowry than forty pounds .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Think of all who marry without a dowry at all .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: You would n't have me go to James Scollard without a dowry ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Well , you know the way we 're situated . If you insist on getting eighty pounds we 'll have to make an overdraft on the bank , and , in the way business is , I do n't know how we 'll ever recover it .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: There wo n't be much left out of eighty pounds when we get what suits us in furniture .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: I could let you have some furniture .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: No , mother . We want to start in a way that is different from this house .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: You 'll want all the money together ?

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: All of it , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: You 'll have to get it so . But you 're very hard , Anna .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: This house would teach any one to look to themselves .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Come upstairs .Anna goes , leftThree hundred pounds of a loss . Eighty pounds with that . I 'm terrified when I think .She goes after AnnaCrofton Crilly comes in from shop . He takes glass of whisky from table , and sits down in arm chair .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: I do n't know what Marianne 's to do at all . She has a shocking lot to contend with . Can anything be got from the old man , I wonder ? Albert Crilly comes in by door , left .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: Well , pa .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Well , Albert . What 's the news in the town , Albert ?

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: They say that you 've backed a bill for Covey .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: If your mother hears that kind of talk she 'll be vexed , Albert .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: But did you back the bill ?

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: For Heaven 's sake , let me alone , Albert . Yes , I backed the bill .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: How much ?

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: You 'll hear all about it from your mother .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: They say the bill was for three hundred .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: It was three or thereabouts .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: ‘ Pon my word , father , the mother will have to take out a mandamus against you .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: with parental dignityDo n't talk to me in that way , Sir .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: It 's scandalous , really . I expect you 've ruined the business .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: I hate the world and all its works and pomps .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: I believe you 've done for the business . I 'm going away .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Then you 've got the other appointment ?

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: Temporary clerkship in the Land Department . I wonder would the mother let me have the money for clothes ?

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: desperatelyDo n't mention it at all to her .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: I have a card from a Dublin tailor in my pocket . If I could pay him for one suit , I could get another on tick .

lg.l: I tell you not to talk to your mother about money . That fellow ,

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: How 's that ?

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Money again . Wants the whole of Anna 's portion down . And Anna 's backing him up , too . I do n't know how your mother can stand it . I do n't like Scollard . Then you wo n't be staying on , Albert , to do the stocktaking in the Workhouse ?

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: No ; they 'll have to get some one else . I 'm glad to be out of that job .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: I 'm not sorry , Albert .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: The mother would expect me to do something queer in my report .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Between you and me , Albert , women are n't acquainted with the working of affairs , and they expect unusual things to happen . Who will they make stocktaker , now ?

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: Young Dobbs , likely . I suppose the whole business about the coal will come out then ?

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: I suppose it will ; but say nothing about it now , Albert . Let the hare sit .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: What does the old man think about it now ?

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: He 's very close to himself . I think he has forgotten all about it .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: I would n't say so .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: Who 's that in the shop , Albert ?

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: Felix Tournour .

sp.speaker: CRILLY
sp.p: risingI wonder what they think about Scollard in the Poor-house .He and Albert go into the shop as Muskerry enters from leftMuskerry is untidily dressed . His boots are unlaced . He walks across the room and speaks pettishly .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: They have n't brought my soup yet . They wo n't give much of their time to me . I 'm disappointed in Anna Crilly . Well , a certain share in this shop was to have gone to Anna Crilly . I 'll get that share , and I 'll hoard it up myself . I 'll hoard it up . And the fifty pounds of my pension , I 'll hoard that up , too . Albert comes in from shop .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: That 's a black fire that 's in the grate . I do n't like the coal that comes into this place .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: Coal , eh , grandpapa .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I said coal .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: We have n't good stores here .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Confound you for your insolence .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: Somebody you know is in the shop — Felix Tournour .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Bid Tournour come in to me .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: talking into the shopYou 're wanted here , Tournour . Come in now or I 'll entertain the boss with “ The Devil 's Rambles . ”He turns to MuskerryI was given the job of stocktaking .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: That 's a matter for yourself .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: I do n't think I 'll take the job now .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Why wo n't you take it ?

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: I do n't know what to say about the fifty tons of coal .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I was too precipitate about the coal . But do n't have me at the loss of fifty pounds through any of your smartness .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: All right , grandfather ; I 'll see you through .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Confound you for a puppy . Felix Tournour enters . He looks prosperous . He has on a loud check suit . He wears a red tie and a peaked cap .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: The Master wants to speak to you , Tournour .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: What Master .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: The boss , Tournour , the boss .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I want you , and that 's enough for you , Tournour .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: I suppose you do n't know , grandpapa , that Tournour has a middling high position in the Poorhouse now .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: What are you saying ?

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: Tournour is Ward-master now .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I was n't given any notice of that .

lg.l: “ The Devil went out for a ramble at night ,
Through Garrisowen Union to see every sight .
“ He saw one in comfort , of that you 'll be sure .
With his back to the fire stands Felix Tournour , ”
He puts his back to fire .

sp.speaker: ALBERT
sp.p: Well , so-long , gents .He goes out by shop door

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Let me see you , Tournour .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: I 'm plain to be seen .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Who recommended you for Ward-master ?

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: Them that had the power .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I would not have done it , Tournour .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: No . And still , d'ye see , I 'm up and not down . Well , I 'll be going .

lg.l: Come back here , Tournour . I made it a rule that no
Ward-master should let drink be brought in to the paupers .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: It 's a pity you 're not Master still !

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: What are you saying ?

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: It 's a pity that you 're not still the Master over us .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Tournour , you 're forgetting yourself .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: Well , maybe you are still the Master .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: How dare you speak to me with such effrontery ? How dare you ?

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: I dunno . I 'm going away now , if your honour has nothing more to say to me .He turns to go

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: You shall not . You shall not , I say .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: You shall not go away until you 've apologised to me .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: Do n't be talking , Thomas Muskerry . You 're not Master over me .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Not the Master over you ?

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: No . There 's an end to your sway , Mr. Muskerry .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Go out of the house . No , stay here . You think I 'm out of the Workhouse . No . That 's not so . I 've claims , great claims , on it still . Not for nothing was I there for thirty years , the pattern for the officials of Ireland .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: Twenty-nine years , I 'm telling you .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: The Guardians will take account of me .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: And maybe they would , too .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: What 's that you 're saying ?

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: The Guardians might take an account of Thomas Muskerry in a way he might n't like .He goes to door

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Come back here , Felix Tournour .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: I 'm not your sub-servant .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Stand here before me .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: You and your before me ! Your back to heaven and your belly to hell .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Go away . Go away out of this .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: Do n't try to down-face me . I know something about you .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: About me !

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: Aye , you and your fifty tons of coal .Muskerry goes back from himGreat claims on the Workhouse have you . The Guardians will take account of you . Will they ? Talk to them about the fifty tons of coal . Go and do that , my pattern of the officials of Ireland ! Tournour goes out by shop . Muskerry stands with his hands on the arm chair .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: This minute I 'll go down to the Guardians and make my complaint .He notices his appearanceI 'm going about all day with my boots unlaced . I 'm falling into bad ways , bad , slovenly ways . And my coat needs brushing , too .He takes off his coat and goes to window and brushes itThat 's Myles Gorman going back to the Workhouse . I could n't walk with my head held as high as that . In this house I am losing my uprightness . I 'll do more than lace my boots and brush my coat . I 'll go down to the Guardians and I 'll pay them back their fifty pounds . Anna Crilly comes in from left with a bowl of soup .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Here 's your soup , grandpapa .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I can n't take it now , Anna .He puts on his coat

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Are you going out , grandpapa ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I 'm going before the meeting of the Board of Guardians .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Are you , grandpapa ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Yes , Anna , I am . I 'm going to pay them back their fifty pounds .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: And have you the fifty pounds ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Your mother has it for me .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Sit down , grandpapa , and take your soup .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: No , Anna , I wo n't take anything until my mind is at rest about the coal . A certain person has spoken to me in a way I 'll never submit to be spoken to again . Mrs. Crilly comes in .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: What has happened to you ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Felix Tournour knows about the coal , Marianne . He can disgrace me before the world .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: And grandpapa wants to go before the Guardians and pay them back the fifty pounds .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Wait until we consult Mr. Scollard .

sp.speaker: Anna goes out
sp.p: MUSKERRY No , Marianne . I 'm not going to be a party to this any longer . I 'm going before the Guardians , and I 'll pay them back their fifty pounds .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Fifty pounds . From what place is fifty pounds to come so easily ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I 'll ask you to give me the fifty pounds , Marianne .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: I 'll do no such thing . Anna is getting married , and she claims her fortune .

lg.l: Anna getting married . This was kept from me . And who is

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: To James Scollard .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: To James Scollard . And so Anna is getting married to my successor , James Scollard . My successor . How well I knew there was some such scheme behind shifting me out of the Workhouse . And Anna Crilly was against me all the time . Well , well , well . I 'll remember this .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: I 'm at great losses since you came here .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I 'm at greater losses , Marianne .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: What losses are you at ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: The loss of my trust , the loss of my dignity , my self-respect , and —

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: I think we did all we could for you .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I 'm going out now to pay back the Guardians the sum due to them from me . I want fifty pounds from you . I claim it , and I have a right to claim it .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: We have no money at all . Listen . Crofton Crilly backed a bill for James Covey , and three hundred pounds has been taken from our account .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Three hundred pounds !

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Yes . Three hundred pounds .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: He backed a bill for three hundred pounds . And do you think , Marianne Crilly , there can be any luck , in a house where such a thing could happen ? I tell you there is no luck nor grace in your house .He puts on his hat and goes to cupboard to get his stick . He opens the cupboard . He turns round

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: greatly movedMy God , my God . I 'm made cry at the things that happen in this house .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: What is it ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: The good meat I brought in . There it is on the floor and the cat mangling it . I 'll go out of this house , and I 'll never put foot into it again .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: And where will you go ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I 'll go before the Board of Guardians and I 'll ask them to provide for me .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: What do you want me to do for you ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Give me fifty pounds , so that I can pay them off now .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Have n't I told you the way I 'm straitened for money ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: You have still in the bank what would save my name .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Do n't be unreasonable . I have to provide for my children .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Your children . Yes , you have to provide for your children . I provided for them long enough . And now you would take my place , my honour , and my self-respect , and provide for them over again .He goes out

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: I 'll have to put up with this , too .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: He has gone down to the Workhouse .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: What is he going to do , mother ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: He says he will ask the Guardians to provide for him .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: It 's not likely they 'll do that for a man with a pension of fifty pounds a year .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: I do n't know what will happen to us .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: He 'll come back , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: He will . But everything will have been made public , and the money will have to be paid .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: at the windowThere he is going down the street , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Which way ?

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Towards the Workhouse . And here 's the doctor 's daughter coming into the shop again , mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: I 'll go out and see her myself .As she goes out she hands Anna a chequeThat 's the last cheque I 'll be able to make out . There 's your eighty pounds , Anna .She goes into the shop

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: We can begin to get the furniture now . She sits down at the table and makes some calculation with a pencil .

stage.stage: The infirm ward in the Workhouse . Entrance from corridor , right . Forward , left , are three beds with bedding folded upon them . Back , left , is a door leading into Select Ward . This door is closed , and a large key is in lock . Fireplace with a grating around it , left . Back , right , is a window with little leaded panes .
It is noon on a May day , but the light inside the ward is feeble .

Two paupers are seated at fire . One of them , Mickie Cripes , is a man of fifty , stooped and hollow-chested , but with quick blue eyes . The other man , Tom Shanley , is not old , but he looks broken and listless . Myles Gorman , still in pauper dress , is standing before window , an expectant look on his face .

Thomas Muskerry enters from corridor . He wears his own clothes , but he has let them get into disorder . His hair and beard are disordered , and he seems very much broken down . Nevertheless , he looks as if his mind were composed .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: It 's dark in here , Michael .

sp.speaker: GRIPES
sp.p: It is , sir .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I find it very spiritless after coming up from the chapel . Do n't pass your whole day here . Go down into the yard .He stands before the windowThis is the first fine day , and you ought to go out along the country road . Ask the Master for leave . It 's the month of May , and you 'll be glad of the sight of the grass and the smell of the bushes . Now here 's a remarkable thing . I venture to think that the like of this has never happened before . Here are the bees swarming at the window pane .

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: You 'll hear my pipes on the road to-day . That 's as sure as the right hand is on my body .He goes out by corridor door

sp.speaker: CRIPES
sp.p: Myles Gorman must have been glad to hear that buzzing .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Why was Myles glad to hear it ?

sp.speaker: SHANLEY
sp.p: He was leaving on the first fine day .

sp.speaker: CRIPES
sp.p: The buzzing at the pane would let any one know that the air is nice for a journey .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I am leaving to-day , myself .

sp.speaker: CRIPES
sp.p: And where are you going , Mr. Muskerry ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I 'm going to a place of my own . Muskerry goes into the Select Ward .

sp.speaker: CRIPES
sp.p: I 'll tell you what brought Thomas Muskerry back to the workhouse to be an inmate in it . Living in a bad house . Living with his own . That 's what brought him back . And that 's what left me here , too .

sp.speaker: SHANLEY
sp.p: listlesslyThe others have the flour , and we may hawk the bran . An old pauper comes into the ward . His face looks bleached . He has the handle of a sweeping-brush for a staff . He moves about the ward , muttering to himself . He seats himself on chair , right .

sp.speaker: THE OLD MAN
sp.p: speaking as if thinking aloudI was at twelve o'clock Mass . Now one o'clock would be a late Mass . I was at Mass at one o'clock . Would n't that be a long time to keep a priest , and he fasting the whole time ?

sp.speaker: CRIPES
sp.p: I 'll tell you what Thomas Muskerry did when he left the bad house he was in .He puts coal on the fire

sp.speaker: THE OLD MAN
sp.p: I was at one o'clock Mass in Skibbereen . I know where Skibbereen is well . In the County Cork . Cork is a big county . As big as Dublin and Wicklow . That 's where the people died when there was the hunger .

sp.speaker: CRIPES
sp.p: He came before the meeting of the Guardians , and he told them he owed them the whole of his year 's pension . Then he got some sort of a stroke , and he broke down . And the Guardians gave him the Select Ward there for himself .

sp.speaker: SHANLEY
sp.p: They did well for him .

sp.speaker: CRIPES
sp.p: Why would n't they give him the Select Ward ? It 's right that he 'd get the little room , and not have to make down the pauper 's bed with the rest of us .

sp.speaker: SHANLEY
sp.p: He was at the altar to-day , and he stayed in the chapel after Mass .

sp.speaker: CRIPES
sp.p: He 'll be here shortly .

sp.speaker: THE OLD MAN
sp.p: Skibbereen ! That 's where the people died when there was the hunger . Men and women without coffins , or even their clothes off . Just buried . Skibbereen I remember well , for I was a whole man then . And the village . For there are people living in it yet . They did n't all die .

sp.speaker: SHANLEY
sp.p: We 'll have somebody else in the Select Ward this evening .

sp.speaker: CRIPES
sp.p: That 's what they were talking about . The nuns are sending a patient up here .

sp.speaker: SHANLEY
sp.p: I suppose the Ward-master will be in here to regulate the room .He rises

sp.speaker: CRIPES
sp.p: Aye , the Ward-master . Felix Tournour , the Ward-master . You 've come to your own place at last , Felix Tournour .

sp.speaker: SHANLEY
sp.p: Felix Tournour will be coming the master over me if he finds me here .Shanley goes out

sp.speaker: CRIPES
sp.p: Felix Tournour ! That 's the lad that will be coming in with his head up like the gander that 's after beating down a child . Christy Clarice enters . He carries a little portmanteau .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: Is Mr. Muskerry here ?

sp.speaker: CRIPES
sp.p: He 's in the room .A sound of water splashing and the movements of a heavy person are heardWill you be speaking with him , young fellow ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: I will .

sp.speaker: CRIPES
sp.p: Tell him , like a good little boy , that the oul ’ men would be under a favour to him if he left a bit of tobacco . You wo n't forget that ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: I wo n't forget it .

sp.speaker: CRIPES
sp.p: I do n't want to be in the way of Felix Tournour . We 're going down to the yard , but we 'll see Mr. Muskerry when he 's going away . Cripes goes out .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: withinIs that you , Christy Clarke ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: It is , Mr. Muskerry .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Have you any news , Christy ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: No news , except that my mother is in the cottage , and is expecting you to-day .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I 'll be in the cottage to-day , Christy . I 'm cleaning myself .A sound of splashing and moving aboutThe Guardians were good to get the little house for me . I 'd as lieve be there as in a mansion . There 's about half an acre of land to the place , and I 'll do work on the ground from time to time , for it 's a good thing for a man to get the smell of the clay .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: And how are you in health , Mr. Muskerry ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I 'm very well in health . I was anointed , you know , and after that I mended miraculously .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: And what about the pension ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I 'm getting three hundred pounds . They asked me to realize the pension . I hope I have life enough before me .He comes out . He has on trousers , coat , and starched shirt . The shirt is soiled and crushed

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: On Saturdays I 'll do my marketing . I 'll come into the town , and I 'll buy the bit of meat for my dinner on Sunday . But what are you doing with this portmanteau , Christy ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: I 'm going away myself .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: To a situation , is it ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: To a situation in Dublin .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I wish you luck , Christy .He shakes hands with the boy , and sits down on a chairI was dreaming on new things all last night . New shirts , new sheets , everything new .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: I want to be something .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: What do you want to be ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: A writer .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: A writer of books , is it ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: Yes , a writer of books .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Listen , now , and tell me do you hear anything . That 's the sound of bees swarming at the window . That 's a good augury for you , Christy .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: All life 's before me .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Will you give heed to what I tell you ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: I 'll give heed to it , Mr. Muskerry .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Live a good life .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: I give heed to you .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Your mother had great hardship in rearing you .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: I know that , Mr. Muskerry , but now I 'm able for the world .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I wish success to all your efforts . Be very careful of your personal appearance .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: I will , Mr. Muskerry .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Get yourself a new cravat before you leave the town .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: I 'll get it .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I think I 'd look better myself if I had a fresher shirt .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: I saw clean shirts of yours before the fire last night in my mother 's house .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I wish I could get one before I leave this place .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: Will I run off and get one for you ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Would you , Christy ? Would it be too much trouble ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: You 're a very willing boy , Christy , and you 're sure to get on .He goes to a little broken mirror on the wallI am white and loose of flesh , and that 's not a good sign with me , Christy . I 'll tell you something . If I were staying here to-night , it 's the pauper 's bed I 'd have to sleep on . Mrs. Crilly comes to the door .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Well , I see you 're making ready for your departure .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: who has become uneasyI am ready for my departure .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: And this young man has come for you , I suppose ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: This young man is minding his own business .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: I 'm going out now to get a shirt for the Master .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: A starched shirt , I suppose , Christy . Go down to our house , and tell Mary to give you one of the shirts that are folded up .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: The boy will go where he was bid go .

lg.l: Oh , very well . Run , Christy , and do the message for the

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I do n't know what brought you here to-day .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Well , I wanted to see you .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: You could come to see me when I was settled down .

sp.speaker: MRS
sp.p: CRILLY Settled in the cottage the Guardians have given you ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Yes , ma'am .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: with nervous excitement , restrainedNo one of us will ever go near the place .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Well , you 'll please yourself .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: You put a slight on us all when you go there to live .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Well , I 've lived with you to my own loss .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Our house is the best house in the town , and I 'm the nearest person to you .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Say nothing more about that .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Well , maybe you do right not to live with us , but you ought not to forsake us altogether .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: And what do you mean by forsaking you altogether ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: When you leave the place and do not even turn your step in our direction it 's a sign to all who want to know that you forsake us altogether .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: What do you want me to do ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Come up to Cross Street with me , have dinner and spend the night with us . People would have less to talk about if you did that .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: You always have a scheme .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Come to us for this evening itself .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I wish you would n't trouble me , woman . Ca n't you see that when I go out of this I want to go to my own place ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: You can go there to-morrow .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Preparations are made for me .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: You do n't know what preparations .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Two pounds of the best beef-steak were ordered to be sent up to-day .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: I would n't trust that woman , Mrs. Clarke , to cook potatoes .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Well , I 'll trust her , ma'am .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: taking Muskerry 's sleeveDo n't go to-day , anyway .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: You 're very anxious to get me to come with you . What do you want from me ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: We want nothing from you . You know how insecure our business is . When it 's known in the town that you forsake us , everybody will close in on us .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: God knows I did everything that a man could do for you and yours . I wo n't forget you . I have n't much life left to me , and I want to live to myself .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: I know . Sure I lie awake at night , too tired to sleep , and long to get away from the things that are pressing in on me . I know that people are glad of their own way , and glad to live in the way that they like . When I heard the birds stirring I cried to be away in some place where I wo n't hear the thing that 's always knocking at my head . The business has to be minded , and it 's slipping away from us like water . And listen , if my confinement comes on me and I worried as I was last year , nothing can save me . I 'll die , surely .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: movedWhat more do you want me to do ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Stay with us for a while , so that we 'll have the name of your support .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I 'll come back to you in a week .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: That would n't do at all . There 's a reason for what I ask . The town must know that you are with us from the time you leave this .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: with emotionGod help me with you all , and God direct me what to do .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: It 's not in you to let us down . Muskerry turns away . His head is bent . Mrs. Crilly goes to him .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Will you never be done taking from me ? I want to leave this and go to a place of my own . Muskerry puts his hand to his eyes . When he lowers his hand again Mrs. Crilly lays hers in it . Christy Clarke comes in . Muskerry turns to him . Muskerry has been crying .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Well , Christy , I 'll be sending you back on another message . Mrs. Crilly makes a sign to Christy not to speak .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Go to your mother and tell her — -

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: I met my mother outside .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Did she get the things that were sent to her ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: My mother was sent away from the cottage .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Who sent your mother away from the cottage ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: Mrs. Crilly sent her away .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: And why did you do that , ma'am ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: I sent Mary to help to prepare the place for you , and the woman was impertinent to Mary —

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Well , ma'am ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: I sent the woman away .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: And so you take it on yourself to dispose of the servants in my house ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: I daresay you 'll take the woman 's part against my daughter .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: No , ma'am , I 'll take no one 's side , but I 'll tell you this . I want my own life , and I wo n't be interfered with .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: I 'm sorry for what occurred , and I 'll apologise to the boy 's mother if you like .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I wo n't be interfered with , I tell you . From this day out I 'm free of my own life . And now , Christy Clarke , go down stairs and tell the Master , Mr. Scollard , that I want to see him . Christy Clarice goes out .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: I may as well tell you something else . None of the things you ordered were sent up to the cottage .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Do you tell me that ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: I went round to the shop , and everything you ordered was sent to us .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: And what is the meaning of that , ma'am ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: If the town knew you were going from us , in a week we would have to put up the shutters .

lg.l: Well , I 'll walk out of this , and when I come to the road

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: We can n't prevent you .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: No , ma'am , you can n't prevent me .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: You 've got your discharge , I suppose ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I 've given three hours ’ notice , and I 'll get my discharge now .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: at corridor doorWe can n't prevent you going if you have the doctor 's discharge .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: The doctor 's discharge ! He would have given it to me —

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: You can n't leave without the doctor 's sanction .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Out of this house I will go to-day . James Scollard enters .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: I believe you want to see me , Mr. Muskerry .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I do , Mr. Scollard . I am leaving the house .

lg.l: I will be glad to take up the necessary formalities for you ,

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: First of all , has the doctor marked my father off the infirmary list ?

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: No , Mrs. Crilly . Now that I recall the list , he has not .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I waited after Mass to-day , and I missed seeing him .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: My father was seriously ill only a short time ago , and I do not believe he is in a fit state to leave the infirmary .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: That certainly has to be considered . Without the doctor explicitly sending you down to the body of the house you are hardly under my jurisdiction , Mr. Muskerry .

lg.l: Mr. Scollard , I ask you to give me leave to go out of the
Workhouse for a day . You can do this on your own responsibility .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: In the present state of his mind it 's not likely he would return to-night . Then if anything happened him your situation is at stake .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I 'm not a pauper . I 'll go out of this to-day without leave or license from any of you .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: As you know yourself , Mr. Muskerry , it would be as much as my situation is worth to let you depart in that way .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Well , go I will .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: I cannot permit it , Mr. Muskerry . I say it with the greatest respect .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: How long will you keep me here ?

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: Until the doctor visits the house .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: That will be on Monday morning .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: And this is Saturday , Mr. Muskerry .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: And where will you put me until Monday ?

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: Other arrangements will be made for you .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: It 's the pauper 's bed you would give me !

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: The old arrangements will continue . Can I do anything further for you , Mr. Muskerry ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: No , you can do nothing further for me . It 's a great deal you have done for me ! It 's the pauper 's bed you have given me !He goes into the Select Ward

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Sit down , Mr. Scollard . I want to speak to you . Mrs. Crilly seats herself at the table . Scollard sits down also .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: The bank manager is in the town to-day , and there are people waiting to tell him whether my father goes to our house or goes away from us .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD No doubt there are , Mrs. Crilly

lg.l: But you have nothing to do with that , Mr. Scollard .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: No , Mrs. Crilly .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: I have my own battle to fight , and a hard battle it is . I have to make bits of myself to mind everything and be prepared for everything .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: No doubt , Mrs. Crilly .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: There are people who will blame me , but they cannot see into my mind .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: Will you come down to the parlour , Mrs. Crilly ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Yes , I 'll go down . She remains seated , looking out steadily before her . Myles Gorman comes in . He is dressed in his own clothes .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: Well , Gorman , what brings you back to the ward ?

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: I just want to do something to my pipes , Master .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: Very well , Gorman . You have your discharge , and you are free to leave .

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: Oh , in a while I 'll be taking the road . He seats himself at the fire and begins to fix the bag of his pipes .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: Now , Mrs. Crilly , come down to the parlour .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: Anna is waiting to see you .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: risingHe will be well cared for here .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: He will , Mrs. Crilly . I will give him all attention .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: He expected to be in a different place to-day , but delay does little harm .

sp.speaker: SCOLLARD
sp.p: Come down to the parlour , Mrs. Crilly , and drink a glass of wine with us . They go out . The door of the Select Ward opens , and Thomas Muskerry appears . He has got a stroke . His breathing makes a noise in his mouth . As he moves he lags somewhat at the right knee . He carries his right hand at his breast . He moves slowly across ward . Felix Tournour enters , carrying a bunch of keys .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: And where are you going ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: in a thickened voiceOw — out .Motioning with left hand . He moves across ward , and goes out on door of corridor

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: Well , you 're not getting back to your snuggery , my oul ’ cod .He goes into the Select Ward and begins to pitch Muskerry 's belongings into the outer ward . First of all come the pillows and clothes off the bedAnd there 's your holy picture , and there 's your holy book .He comes out holding another book in official binding . He opens it and reads“ Marianne , born May the 20th , 1870 . ”He turns back some pages and readsThomas Muskerry wrote this , 1850 — “ In the pleasant month of May , When the lambkins sport and play , As I roved out for recreation , I spied a comely maid , Sequestered in the shade , And on her beauty I gazed in admiration . ” “ I said I greatly fear That Mercury will draw near , As once he appeared unto Venus , Or as it might have been To the Carthaginian Queen , Or the Grecian Wight called Polyphemus . ” Muskerry comes back to the ward . He stands looking stupidly at the heap Tournour has thrown out . Tournour throws down the book . Muskerry goes towards the open door of the ward . Felix Tournour closes the door deliberately turns the key and holds the key in his hand .

sp.speaker: TOURNOUR
sp.p: You have no more to do with your snug little ward , Mr. Muskerry .He puts the key on his bunch and goes out

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: muttering with slack lips and cheeksIt 's — it 's — the pau — pauper 's bed they 've given me .

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: turning round his faceWho 's there ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: It 's — it 's — Thomas Muskerry .

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: Is that the Master ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: It 's — it 's the pauper 's bed they 've given me .

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: Can I give you any hand , Master ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: I 'll want to make — the bed . Give me a hand to make the bed .Gorman comes over to himMy own sheet and blanket is here . I need n't lie on a pauper 's sheet . Whose bed is this ?

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: It 's the middle bed , Master . It 's my own bed .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: helplesslyWhat bed will I take , then ?

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: My bed . I wo n't be here .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: And where are you going ?

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: I 'm leaving the house this day . I 'll be going on the roads .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Myles — Myles Gorman . The man that was without family or friends . Myles Gorman . Help me to lay down the mattress . Where will you sleep to-night , Myles Gorman ?

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: At Mrs. Muirnan 's , a house between this and the town of Ballinagh . I have n't the money to pay , but she 'll give me the place for to-night . Now , Master , I 'll spread the sheet for you .They spread the sheet on the bed .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Can you go down the stairs , Myles Gorman ? I tried to get down the stairs and my legs failed me .

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: One of the men will lead me down .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: resting his hand on the bed and standing upSure one of the men will lead me down the stairs , too . Myles Gorman spreads blanket on bed . He stands up , takes pipes , and is ready to go out . Muskerry becomes more feeble . He puts himself on the bed .

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Myles — Myles Gorman — come back .

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: What will I do for you , Master ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Say a prayer for me .

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: What prayer will I say , Master ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: Say “ God be good to Thomas Muskerry . ”

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: taking off his hat“ God be good to Thomas Muskerry , the man who was good to the poor . ” Is that all , Master ?

sp.speaker: MUSKERRY
sp.p: That 's — that 's all . Gorman goes to the door .

sp.speaker: GORMAN
sp.p: In a little while you 'll hear my pipes on the road . He goes out . There is the sound of heavy breathing from the bed . Then silence . The old pauper with the staff enters . He is crossing the ward when his attention is taken by the humming of the bees at the window pane . He listens for a moment .

sp.speaker: THE OLD PAUPER
sp.p: A bright day , and the clay on their faces . That 's what I saw . And we used to be coming from Mass and going to the coursing match . The hare flying and the dogs stretching after her up the hill . Fine dogs and fine men . I saw them all . Christy Clarke comes in . He goes to table for his bag . He sees the figure on the bed , and goes over .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: I 'm going now , Mister Muskerry . Mister Muskerry ! Mister Muskerry ! Oh ! the Master is dead .He runs back to the doorMrs. Crilly . Mrs. Crilly .He goes back to the bed , and throws himself on his kneesOh ! I 'm sorry you 're gone , Thomas Muskerry .

sp.speaker: THE OLD PAUPER
sp.p: And is he gone home , too ! And the bees humming and all ! He was the best of them . Each of his brothers could lift up their plough and carry it to the other side of the field . Four of them could clear a fair . But their fields were small and poor , and so they scattered . Mrs. Crilly comes in .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: Christy Clarke , what is it ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: The Master is dead .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: My God , my God !

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: Will I go and tell them below ?

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: No . Bring no one here yet . We killed him . When everything is known that will be known .

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: I 'll never forget him , I think .

sp.speaker: MRS. CRILLY
sp.p: What humming is that ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTY
sp.p: The bees at the window pane . And there 's Myles Gorman 's pipes on the road . The drear call of the pipes is heard .

sp.speaker: END OF PLAY
sp.p: “ Thomas Muskerry ” was first produced on May 5th , 1910 , by the Abbey Theater Company , at the Abbey Theater , Dublin , with the following cast :—
